questions.text: Which of the following blood groups can be given to a patient having Bombay blood group?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Oh (Bombay) blood group blood can be transfused to Bombay blood group patients.

The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. The absence of this H antigen results in the absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

However, the O blood group has an H antigen. Thus if a patient with the Bombay blood group is transfused with the O blood group blood, the anti-H antibodies in the Bombay blood group patient react with the H antigen present in the O blood group. This can lead to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with the Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.

Other less common systems of blood grouping include MNSs, Lutheran, Kell, and Kidd systems of blood grouping. 

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical condition is a hexanucleotide repeat  disorder?
questions.solution:
Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder.

The C9ORF72 gene is associated with a hexanucleotide repeat expansion mutation. It is a common cause of both FTD and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The mutation leads to the production of abnormal RNA and proteins, causing cellular toxicity.

Frontotemporal dementia presents with early personality changes (frontal lobe involvement) and loss of social restraints initially, followed by memory loss. Other features include loss of insight, easy distractibility, reduced concern or empathy for others, emotional lability or withdrawal, impulsiveness, poor self-care, and perseveration.

There is a second type of presentation of FTD, which is characterized by an early and progressive change in language, with problems of expression of language or severe naming difficulty, and problems with word meaning.

The classic imaging findings seen in FTD are preferential atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes with occipitoparietal sparing

Histopathology shows Pick cells (swollen neurons) in affected areas of the brain. These neurons appear larger than normal and are typically filled with cytoplasmic inclusions known as Pick bodies (intraneuronal argentophilic inclusions).

Other options:

Option B: Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It occurs due to CGG repeats in the untranslated regions(UTR) of the FMR1 gene. 

Option C: Huntington's disease is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction. 

Option D: Myotonic dystrophy is caused by expansions of CTG triplet repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene.  It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Which is the new online software launched under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) by the government to monitor TB patients?
questions.solution:
NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB).

Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients to monitor the Revised National Tuberculosis Programme (RNTCP). This system stores information about the patient, medical history, diagnosis, co-morbidities and lab reports. 

The system has been developed jointly by the Central TB Division of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and National Informatics Centre (NIC) and it was launched by the Government of India in June 2012. This is used by health functionaries at various levels across the country in association with Central TB Division (CTD), Ministry of Health & Family Welfare.

NIKSHAY covers various aspects of controlling TB using technological innovations.

Apart from web-based technology, SMS services have been used effectively for communication with patients and monitoring the program on a day-to-day basis.

Other options:

Option B: Nikusth is the new online software for monitoring leprosy patients.

Option C: Nischay is a pregnancy test kit.

Option D: Axshya is a project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between the government and civil society.

questions.text: Calculate the mid-parental height of a male child whose father's and mother's height are 183 cm and 175 cm, respectively.
questions.solution:
The mid-parental height for a male child with a father who is 183 cm and a mother who is 175 cm tall will be 185.5 cm.

Mid-parental height for a male child = (Mother's height + Father's height / 2 ) + 6.5

Calculation :

Father's height = 183 cms

Mother's height = 175 cms

Mid parental height = (183 + 175 / 2 ) + 6.5 =  185.5 cm

Mid-parental height for a female child  = (Mother's height + Father's height / 2 ) - 6.5

questions.text: The heart of the activated sludge process is:
questions.solution:
The activated sludge process is a part of the secondary sewage treatment and the heart of this process is the aeration tanks. 

Related Pearl: Modern Sewage Treatment

Primary treatment

  • Screening
    • A large metal screen is used to intercept large floating objects like dead animals, wood, rags, etc., so as to prevent clogging
  • Grit chamber
    • It is also called detritus chamber
    • It allows for the settlement of heavier solids like gravel or sand and permits the organic matter to flow through
    • The grit that is collected at the bottom is then disposed of.
  • Primary sedimentation
    • In a primary sedimentation tank, sewage is allowed to flow slowly so that suspended matter is sediments to form sludge which is then removed without disturbing the rest of the operation.
    • Biological action takes place here and breaks down complex organic solids
    • Scum in the form of grease and fat collect on top of the tank
    • Sometimes, chemicals like lime are added to the effluent to enhance precipitation

Secondary treatment

  • Trickling filter method
    • The trickling or percolating filter is a bed of crushed stones or clinker
    •  Effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is spread over the filter bed and as it percolates through it, it gets oxidized by bacterial flora. There is no actual filtration that occurs.
    • The oxidized sewage forms a light green material called humus and it is then led into secondary sedimentation tanks.
  • Activated sludge process
    • This is done in place of the trickling filter method. Both are not done together
    • The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tank
    • In these tanks, the effluent from primary sedimentation is mixed with activated or return sludge (sludge from the final settling tank) and is then exposed to aeration for 6 to 8 hours.
    • During aeration, organic matter is oxidized into carbon dioxide, nitrates and water with the help of aerobic bacteria in the activated sludge.
  • Secondary sedimentation
    • From the trickling filters or aeration tanks, the oxidized sewage is allowed into a secondary sedimentation tank where it is held for 2 – 3 hours.
    • Here, aerated sludge or activated sludge is formed, part of which is pumped back into an aeration tank
  • Sludge digestion
    • Sludge digestion can be done by incubating it under favorable conditions to allow anaerobic auto-digestion. This is done in sludge digestion tanks.
    • Disposal of sludge is also done by sea disposal
    • Sludge can also be disposed of by composting with solid refuse
  • Disposal of effluent
    • Disposal of effluent can be done by dilution in water bodies which has to then be chlorinated
    • Disposal on land is possible if the effluent can be used for irrigation purposes

questions.text: A patient came to the clinic, and the following test was performed, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is being tested here?
questions.solution:
The test being performed here is the Trendelenburg test, which is done to check the action of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are powerful abductors of the hip supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

A positive Trendelenburg test on the right side indicates a right superior gluteal nerve injury, and vice versa.
When the patient stands on his left foot, there is drooping of the right; this is a positive Trendelenburg test on the left side.

Normally, when the leg is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus on the opposite (unsupported) side exert traction on the hip bone. This results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in an upright position.

If the gluteus medius and minimus are paralysed, the pelvis drops on the contralateral side. This is known as a positive Trendelenburg sign. It is positive in the paralysis of the hip abductors and in developmental dysplasia of the hip. A characteristic lurching gait is seen.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of recommended ANC visits during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The recommended ideal number of antenatal visits is 12–14 during pregnancy.

The generally recommended ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14:

  • Monthly visits up to 28 weeks
  • Two weekly visits between 28-36 weeks
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks onward.
  • This means a total of 12–14 visits.

According to the 2016 WHO ANC model, the antenatal visits should be a minimum of 8 visits:

  • Contact 1: Upto 12 weeks
  • Contact 2: 20 weeks
  • Contact 3: 26 weeks
  • Contact 4: 30 weeks
  • Contact 5: 34 weeks
  • Contact 6: 36 weeks
  • Contact 7: 38 weeks
  • Contact 8: 40 weeks
  • Return for delivery at 41 weeks if not delivered yet. The trimester-wise contacts would be 1 contact in the first trimester, 2 contacts in the second trimester and 5 in the third trimester. 

The older Focused Antenatal Care (FANC) guidelines by the WHO recommended a minimum of 4 visits, as given below

  • 1st visit: Within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as pregnancy is suspected, for the registration of pregnancy and 1st antenatal check-up.
  • 2nd visit: Between 24-26 weeks
  • 3rd visit: At 32 weeks
  • 4th visit: Between 36-38 weeks
  • Return for delivery at 41 weeks if not delivered yet.

A booked case is one that has at least 3 antenatal visits, with two visits in the third trimester.

questions.text: Calculate the dependency ratio in this family. Mr J, age 68 years, Mrs J age 59, their son’s age 30 years, his wife’s age is 27 years and grandson is 5 years old.
questions.solution:
The dependency ratio for this family will be 66.6%. 

The dependent population includes children Population under 15 years and above 65 years are part of the numerator used to calculate the total dependency ratio. This is because this population is considered the dependent population.

Here,

Family members under 15 years = 1

Family members above 65 years = 1

Total population under 15 years and above 65 years = 1+1 = 2 (Numerator)

Total population in 15-65 years group = 3

Total dependency ratio = 2/3 x 100 = 66.6%

The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15–65 years. It is also called the societal dependency ratio. It can also be divided into the young-age and old-age dependency ratios.

Note: As of mid-year 2020, the dependency ratio of India is 48.7%.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing sections of his fingers, and developmental delay. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) involved in the salvage pathway.

Purines produced in the body or introduced through diet can be converted to nucleoside triphosphates to be reused by the body. This pathway is called the salvage pathway for purines as shown in the image below.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). An increase in guanine and hypoxanthine eventually gets converted into uric acid, There is increased de novo purine synthesis.

The clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia. The excess uric acid can form kidney stones (urolithiasis) or deposits in joints as urate crystals (gouty arthritis).

The treatment of this condition includes:

  • Allopurinol or febuxostat for hyperuricemia
  • Behavioural management using restraints for self-mutilation
  • High fluid intake, reduced fructose and purine intake

Partial deficiency of HGPRT leads to Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency leads to severe T-cell deficiency with normal B-cell function. Patients present with autoimmune diseases and opportunistic infections.

Option C: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) is another enzyme along with HGPRT to be involved in the salvage of purine bases to nucleotides. 

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to sparse or defective T cells and B cells. Patients suffer from severe immunodeficiency and often succumb to fatal infections. 

 

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Febuxostat

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.solution:
Imatinib is the drug of choice for gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It has a dominant role in tumors involving ABL, KIT, or EGFR kinases. It is the chemotherapy agent of choice in the chronic phase of chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML) and GIST. 

Adverse effects:

  • Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting
  • Fluid retention, edema, and periorbital swelling
  • Myelosuppression

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus. The most common mutation is the c-KIT mutation. GIST can also occur with SDH mutation and NF-1 mutation in neurofibromatosis-1.

GIST has specific tumor markers i.e., CD117 (c-KIT mutation) and DOG-1.

Succinyl dehydrogenase deficient (SDH) deficient GIST is commonly seen in Carney’s triad.

Carney’s triad:

  • Gastric GIST (succinyl dehydrogenase deficient)
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extra adrenal paraganglioma

    Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells.

     

Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead. 

During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.

Other options:

Option A: Sunitinib is a multiple kinase inhibitor that is used in imatinib-resistant GIST and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.

Option C: Sorafenib is also a multiple kinase inhibitor that is used in the treatment of renal cancer and imatinib-resistant GIST. 

Option D: Dasatinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor and is used in imatinib-resistant CML.

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of rice watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery 2 days ago. Selective culture media is shown below. Identify the likely organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of food poisoning with rice watery diarrhea and yellow-coloured colonies on thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS) is suggestive of vibrio cholera.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice-water stools) associated with effortless vomiting.

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea. 

Thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS) is a selective and differential medium used for the culture of Vibrio species. Vibrio cholerae produces yellow-colored colonies against a green background on TCBS.

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Antibiotics that can be used include fluoroquinolones, tetracycline, azithromycin, ampicillin, or trimethoprim -sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

Other options:

Option B: Vibrio alginolyticus has been associated with infections of the eyes, ears, and wounds in human beings exposed to seawater.

Option C:.Vibrio vulnificus may form colorless colonies on TCBS agar.

Option D: Vibrio parahemolyticus forms transparent colonies with a green center on TCBS agar.

The given image is of colonies formed by vibrio parahemolyticus.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. On oral examination, a pseudomembrane is seen over the tonsils. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
This child with pseudomembrane over tonsil has diphtheria, in which the toxin inactivates the elongation factor EF-2.

Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa also produces toxins with a similar mechanism of action.

This infection presents as fever and sore throat, which progresses to dyspnea due to obstruction by the pseudomembrane. Bull's neck appearance is seen due to cervical lymphadenitis. Complications like damage to the heart (myocarditis), kidney (tubular necrosis), liver, and adrenal glands can develop due to the toxin.

Neisser's or Albert's stain will show the bacilli with metachromatic granules situated at the poles of the bacilli. Tellurite blood agar is the selective culture medium.
It is treated mainly by neutralizing with antitoxin and antibiotics to arrest more toxin production.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in GERD?
questions.solution:
Metoclopramide has both antiemetic and prokinetic action and is used in the treatment of GERD.

In GERD, the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) weakens or relaxes, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus, causing irritation and symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation. Metoclopramide is useful in this condition because it increases LES tone, preventing acid reflux, and enhances gastric emptying by promoting gastrointestinal motility. Additionally, it reduces nausea and vomiting by blocking dopamine D2 receptors in the central nervous system. These combined effects help alleviate the symptoms and discomfort associated with GERD.

Metoclopramide works in GERD by enhancing gastrointestinal motility through its antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors. In GIT, acetylcholine increases gastrointestinal motility and increases the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone. Therefore, D2 receptor inhibition augments ACh release and enhances GI motility and LES tone. Additionally, it exerts antiemetic effects by blocking D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone of the central nervous system. The combined actions help alleviate symptoms associated with GERD.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuing metoclopramide and administering anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

Other options :

Option A: Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT and does not suppress vomiting caused by motion sickness. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Option C: Loperamide has μ opioid receptor activity and is an orally active antidiarrheal agent. The drug is more potent than morphine as an antidiarrheal agent and penetrates the CNS poorly. It is effective in patients with 5-fluorouracil-induced diarrhea and can be regarded as the treatment of choice. Loperamide is effective against traveler’s diarrhea and can be used alone or in combination. If clinical improvement in acute diarrhea does not occur within 48 hours, loperamide should be discontinued.

Option D - Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist that is structurally similar to meperidine. It is used in the treatment of acute, chronic, and traveller's diarrhea. Upon administration, it undergoes de-esterification to difenoxin, which is its active metabolite. Its side effects include constipation, toxic megacolon, paralytic ileus and can give rise to CNS depression in children.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presented with symptoms of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances for the past 1 week. She has a history of two similar episodes over the last 5 years. She has no history of elated mood, racing thoughts, or decreased sleep. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances with a past history of two similar episodes is suggestive of recurrent depressive disorder.

Recurrent depressive disorder, also known as recurrent depression, and high-functioning depression, is listed in the DSM-5 under persistent depressive disorder. It causes consistent feelings of hopelessness, hollowness, and low self-esteem lasting less than two-week intervals during which depressive episodes occur. People with recurrent depressive disorder have more severe symptoms and have an episodic disorder, which sets them apart from people with dysthymia. Patients with the disorder would meet the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder if their epi­sodes lasted longer

Other options:

Option B: Cyclothymia is a chronic disorder characterized by at least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms (that do not meet the full criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes). It is a symptomatically milder form of bipolar II disorder.

Option C: Dysthymia (persistent depressive disorder) is characterized by at least 2 years of depressed mood that does not satisfy the criteria for a major depressive episode and with no episodes of mania or hypomania. In children, a diagnosis of dysthymia is made if depressive symptoms are present for more than 1 year.

Option D: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by low mood, anhedonia (lack of interest in usual activities), loss of appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, and/or suicidal thoughts. Decreased serotonin, norepinephrine or dopamine secretion by neurons is implicated in the development of depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of secondary messengers?

choices.text: They transmit signals from cell surface receptors  to intracellular receptors.
Regulation of cellular processes such as metabolism and gene expression
Integration of multiple signaling pathways within the cell

questions.solution:
Direct activation of DNA replication is not a function of secondary messengers.

Secondary messengers are intracellular molecules that relay and amplify signals from extracellular stimuli, such as hormones, neurotransmitters, or growth factors. They act as intermediaries between cell surface receptors and the internal signalling pathways that execute the cellular response. Secondary messengers are crucial for translating external signals into appropriate cellular actions.

They carry the message from the cell surface receptor to other parts of the cell, initiating a series of actions that lead to a response and help control different cellular activities, including metabolism, growth, and how cells respond to external signals.

Types of Secondary Messengers:

  • Cyclic AMP (cAMP): Increases activity in the cell by activating other proteins.
  • Cyclic GMP (cGMP): Similar to cAMP, it activates proteins and affects various functions like muscle relaxation.
  • Inositol Triphosphate (IP3): Helps release calcium from inside the cell, which can influence many cellular activities.
  • Diacylglycerol (DAG): Works with IP3 to activate other proteins that affect cell functions.
  • Calcium Ions (Ca²⁺): Act as a messenger to control various processes such as muscle contractions and neurotransmitter release.

questions.text: A 23-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the hospital with a history of abdominal pain, dehydration, weakness, and lethargy. Which of the following kidney segments is associated with maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.

The driving force for water reabsorption is a trans tubular osmotic gradient established by the reabsorption of solutes.

Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): Sodium is reabsorbed along with various inorganic and organic substances- chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, lactate, glucose, and amino acids. In the early PCT, the main sodium channels used for reabsorption are Na+-glucose cotransporter (SGLT), Na+-H+ exchanger, Na+-amino acid cotransporter, Na+-phosphate cotransporter. In the distal PCT, the high chloride concentration in the lumen favors NaCl reabsorption, driven by the Cl− gradient. 

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

The dilution of urine in water diuresis mainly occurs in the distal parts of the nephron. The proximal convoluted tubule absorbs water and solutes in equal proportions, while the descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to only water. As a result, the urine is concentrated as it enters the ascending limb.

The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water. There is reabsorption of solutes and thus, urine gets diluted. In the absence of vasopressin seen in water diuresis, the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct also remain impermeable to water, while sodium continues to get reabsorbed. Urine becomes hypo-osmolar to plasma. Thus, a large volume of dilute urine is excreted.

In chronic alcoholics, the production and release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, can be impaired. Alcohol inhibits the secretion of ADH from the pituitary gland. This leads to a decreased ability to concentrate urine and increases diuresis, resulting in excessive loss of water. Consequently, the kidneys reabsorb less water, causing dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Over time, chronic suppression of ADH can lead to persistent polyuria and the risk of developing chronic dehydration and electrolyte disturbances, such as hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with visual adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. It is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

questions.text: Paris green dust is used to eliminate the larval form of _________________.
questions.solution:
Paris green is a commonly used larvicide agent against surface feeders like Anopheles larvae.

Paris green (Copper acetoarsenite) is an insecticide, which is a green powder that has 50% arsenious oxide. It is a stomach poison and to be effective, it must be ingested by the larvae. 

The larvae of Anopheles are surface feeders as they lie parallel to the surface of the water due to the absence of a siphon tube. In contrast, Culicine larvae like Aedes, Culex, and Mansonia have a siphon tube that helps them to suspend in water with their head downwards and therefore not affected by pair green.

Other commonly used larvicides include:

  • Mineral oils - diesel oil, kerosene, fractions of crude oils, mosquito larvicidal oil
  • Synthetic insecticides - Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, and Abat

Larvicides that are not recommended include organochlorine compounds like DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane)and HCH (hexachlorocyclohexane). This is because they have a long residual effect, and contaminate water. Vector mosquitoes may also develop resistance to these compounds.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to defect in the biogenesis of _________________.
questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is due to a defect in the biogenesis of peroxisomes.

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

  • Weakness, hypotonia.
  • Neonatal seizures
  • Eye abnormalities.

Biochemical findings will show :

  • Abnormalities in the synthesis of bile acids
  • Marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond a few months.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with complaints of headache, seizures and blurred vision. His BP was recorded as 220/120 mmHg. Which of the following will be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypertensive crisis (BP > 160/110 mmHg). The preferred drug to manage a hypertensive patient in an emergency is IV labetalol.

Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a hypertensive crisis. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and has a good safety profile.

Labetalol is a nonselective β blocker and vascular α blocker. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.

It is available in oral form for the treatment of chronic hypertension and as an intravenous formulation for use in hypertensive emergencies. It can be used in the setting of a pregnancy-induced hypertensive crisis.

Other options: 

Option A: IV Hydralazine: It is a vasodilator used in the treatment of heart failure, and hypertensive emergencies, especially preeclampsia. The drug is used as a combination pill containing isosorbide dinitrate (BiDil) in the treatment of heart failure. The important side effect of hydralazine is drug-induced lupus.

Option B: Oral Nifedipine: It is a calcium channel blocker (CCB), a class of medications commonly used to lower blood pressure by relaxing the blood vessels. They work by blocking the influx of calcium into smooth muscle cells, leading to vasodilation and reduced peripheral resistance. They are safer alternatives to use in pregnant patients with Asthma as they do not cause vasoconstriction and would not worsen it.

Option D: Oral Methydopa: Methyldopa is a selective alpha-2 receptor agonist and is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with a cough, fever and pneumonitis. Urine examination shows the following basophilic inclusion bodies. Which of the following organisms is responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent is cytomegalovirus (CMV) based on the clinical symptoms of immunosuppression and the presence of the owl's eye appearance on urinary examination.

A cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as an owl’s eye appearance.

CMV is the largest virus in the herpes family of viruses. It causes the following conditions:

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection such as fever and rash 
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

CMV spreads through contact with salivary secretions and sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

Laboratory diagnosis is by recovery of the virus from urine, saliva, or other bodily fluids into human fibroblast cells. Antibody demonstration using ELISA is used for diagnosis of primary infection.

Other options:

Option B: Epstein Barr virus: Conditions associated with EBV infection are

  • Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis): fever, pharyngitis, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Burkitt's lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • EBV‐associated lymphoproliferative disease

Option C: Herpes simplex virus causes cutaneous infections like herpes labialis caused by viral reactivation in febrile patients. It presents as blisters around the mouth, cheeks, and forehead. Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis are the most frequent manifestations of primary herpes infections. HSV esophagitis presents as dysphagia, sub-sternal pain, and weight loss. 

Option D: Toxoplasma gondii causes Acute congenital toxoplasmosis may manifest as fever, jaundice, petechial rashes, microphthalmia, cataract, glaucoma, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, myocarditis, cerebral calcifications, and chorioretinitis.

Most infections in adults who are immunocompetent are usually asymptomatic. Active progression of infection is more likely in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders has an impaired thermoregulatory mechanism?
questions.solution:
Heat stroke is a severe heat disorder that occurs when the body's thermoregulatory mechanism fails. Sweating is absent in this condition. 

Heat stroke is likely to occur when the body temperature rises to 106-108 °F (normal 98.6 °F).

Heatstroke symptoms indicate a complete loss of thermoregulatory function. Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. 

The patients present with three main symptoms: hot, dry skin, dilated pupils, and a rectal temperature > 106°F. At these high temperatures, the body's temperature-regulating mechanisms often fail.

Heat stroke can occur in two forms:

  • Classic heat stroke (CHS) is seen in elderly individuals with chronic diseases who are predisposed to heat-related illnesses.
  • Exertional heat stroke (EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. 

Heat stroke is a medical emergency, and the patient should receive treatment as soon as possible to decrease their temperature. The management involves actively cooling the patient by moving them to a cool place, applying a cold cloth, and giving them a cold water bath. Fluid replacement should also be done.

Other options: 

Option A: Heat syncope is caused by prolonged standing and working in a hot environment. The intact thermoregulatory mechanism causes vasodilation and venous pooling, which reduces blood flow to the heart and brain. This results in a syncopal attack and unconsciousness. Treatment involves recovery by lying down.

Option B: Heat cramps are a mild heat disorder caused by working in a hot environment. The intact thermoregulatory mechanism causes profuse sweating and loss of electrolytes, resulting in muscle pain and cramps. Treatment includes the replacement of electrolyte fluids.

Option D: Heat exhaustion/ heat collapse is due to excess vasodilation due to intact thermoregulatory mechanism which leads to reduced diastolic filling of the heart. The patient presents with dilated pupils and loss of consciousness. Treatment involves making the patient lie down and replacing fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correlation coefficient (R) of the given scattergram?
questions.solution:
The given scattergram demonstrates a strong negative correlation between the X and Y variables. The correct correlation coefficient (R) value in this case would be -0.9.

A scattergram is a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along the two axes. Each point on the graph signifies a pair of values from the same observation. The pattern of the resulting points reveals if any correlation exists. A scattergram with positive correlation (R-value > 0) means high values of one variable are associated with high values of another variable. One with a negative correlation (R-value < 0) means high values of one variable are associated with low values of the other variable.

In the given graph, the data points show increasing values on the x-axis correspond with decreasing values on the y-axis and vice-versa (negative correlation). The “line of best fit” for the given scattergram will have data points closer to the line, demonstrating a strong negative correlation (R-value closer to -1).

 

Determining a correlation coefficient (R) involves finding the “line of best fit” (an imaginary straight line) to the plotted data points. The closer the data points to this straight line, the stronger the linear correlation between the two variables.

questions.text: Relative bradycardia is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, relative bradycardia is seen in brucellosis.

Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Brucella species, typically contracted through direct contact with infected animals or consumption of unpasteurized dairy products. The clinical presentation includes undulating fever, relative bradycardia, musculoskeletal symptoms like arthritis and myalgia, general malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, neurological symptoms in neuro brucellosis, presenting as meningitis or encephalitis. In men, epididymal-orchitis can occur, presenting as testicular pain and swelling.

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis includes:

  • Polymerase chain reaction
  • Blood culture with the Castaneda method
  • Serological methods include standard agglutination test (SAT), complement fixation test, Coomb’s antiglobulin test, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).
  • Tests for animals and animal products: Milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with IM streptomycin and oral doxycycline. The prevention of brucellosis can be achieved by pasteurizing milk and other milk products.

Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign, is observed when patients exhibit a lower heart rate than anticipated in relation to an increase in body temperature. Body temperature is commonly regarded as a factor that independently influences heart rate. It is estimated that for each 1°C (1.8°F) rise in temperature, the heart rate typically increases by approximately 15-20 beats per minute.

While this pulse-temperature dissociation is not highly sensitive or specific for establishing a diagnosis, it can still prove beneficial in resource-limited settings due to its easy accessibility and simplicity.

Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include: 

  • Salmonella typhi
  • Brucella (brucellosis)
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
  • Leptospira interrogans
  • Legionella pneumophila
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Plasmodium spp. (malaria)

Noninfectious causes include:

  • Drug fever
  • Beta-blocker use
  • Central nervous system lesions
  • Malignant lymphoma
  • Factitious fever

It was found that relative bradycardia as a feature of a specific disease only occurs in diseases caused by organisms that are both gram-negative and intracellular.

Other options:

Shigellosis, pertussis, and dengue show tachycardia on clinical examination. ( Option A, B & C)

questions.text: Which of the following is a category C bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:

Bioterrorism refers to the intentional release of a harmful agent by attackers to cause diseases or fatalities within the human population or impact food crops and livestock. The aim is to instil fear among civilians or influence governmental actions.

As per the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the agents associated with bioterrorism are grouped into three distinct categories, namely A, B and C. There is no designated Category D within this classification.

Category C bioterrorism agents encompass emerging pathogens, such as Nipah and Hantavirus. These agents possess characteristics that make them susceptible to potential engineering for widespread dissemination in the future. Factors contributing to this risk include their ready availability, elevated mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of both production and dissemination.

Hantaviruses, classified under Bunyaviridae, are rodent-borne viruses primarily transmitted through inhalation of the virus present in the dried excreta of rodents. It causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) or hantavirus pulmonary syndrome.

questions.text: A man who was arrested died while he was in police custody. Who will conduct the inquest in this case?
questions.solution:
A magistrate inquest will be carried out for death under police custody.

BNSS 196/Section 176 Cr. P.C. deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Death under police custody
  • Death due to police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, borstal schools
  • Dowry death
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Exhumation
  • Death or disappearance of any person, or rape of a woman who is under the custody of police or any other person authorized by the court.

Other options:

Option A: 194 BNSS or Section 174 CrPC deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence. In all cases where the police normally conduct inquests, the magistrate can hold an additional inquest, or in place of the police inquest.

Option B: Coroner's Inquest is not practised in India. It is done in the U.K. and the U.S.A. The coroner, who is usually a first-class magistrate or attorney, conducts an inquest in all unnatural and suspicious deaths. The doctor is summoned to his Court to give evidence at the inquest.  

Option C: The medical examiner's system is not followed in India. It is followed in certain states of the USA and Japan. A medical practitioner known as a 'Medical Examiner' is appointed to perform the functions of a Coroner. He gets first-hand information on the investigation and crime scene, which, when correlated with autopsy findings, carves out a better picture.
Though he is not entitled to any judicial powers, the inquest conducted in the presence of a doctor makes it superior to any other method.

A 14-year-old girl presents with café-au-lait macules and lisch nodules. What is the most likely diagnosis?

NF- Neurofibromatosis

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the patient with café-au-lait macules and lisch nodules is Neurofibromatosis- 1. 

Neurofibromatosis (NF) is an autosomal dominant disorder. NF type 1 (NF-1) is the most prevalent type and is caused by loss of function mutation of the NF-1 gene. The protein affected is neurofibromin. NF-I is also known as von Recklinghausen's disease. 

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  1. Six or more café-au-lait macules
  2. Axillary or inguinal freckling
  3. Two or more iris lisch nodules
  4. Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma.
  5. A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia
  6. Optic gliomas
  7. A first-degree relative with NF-1

The image below shows axillary freckling and café-au-lait spots seen in NF-1.

Other options:

It is an autosomal dominant condition.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with cough for 15 days. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological findings and clinical history are suggestive of tuberculosis.

Once Mycobacterium tuberculosis enters the macrophage, it inhibits the formation of the phagolysosome. This allows it to replicate unchecked. M. tuberculosis recruits a host protein coronin to block the fusion of phagosome and lysosome. Th1 response to M. tuberculosis is mounted about three weeks following the infection. The antigen-presenting cells (APCs) present mycobacterial antigens to the T-cells in the lymph nodes and release IL-12 and IL-18 to cause the differentiation of T-cells into Th1 cells. Th1 cells produce IFN-γ. IFN-γ is the critical step in the body's defense against M. tuberculosis. It acts by activating macrophages, causing phagolysosome maturation, and inducing nitric oxide synthase enzyme to form more reactive nitrogen species. It also mobilizes anti-bacterial compounds like defensins and stimulates autophagy.

Th1 response leads to the formation of a granuloma and caseous necrosis. Macrophages that are activated by the action of IFN-γ differentiate into epithelioid histiocytes. These are the cells that actually aggregate to form a granuloma. Some epithelioid cells may also fuse to form a giant cell.

The microscopic picture shows the caseating granuloma. Eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells and lymphocytes can be seen. Epitheloid cells merge to form Langhan's giant cell where nuclei are arranged in a horseshoe shape (a characteristic feature of tuberculosis). 

Clinically, tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, breathing difficulty, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and swollen lymph nodes. Chest radiograph shows tree-in-bud pattern, infiltrates, and cavity formation predominantly in the upper lobes.

Other options:

Option B: Leprosy presents with skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation. Histopathology shows noncaseating granulomas.

Option C: Sarcoidosis shows giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions and noncaseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

Option D: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection that shows hyperplasia of the capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells with caseating granulomas.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure
questions.solution:
The labelled structure is the Internal capsule.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • anterior limb
  • genu
  • posterior limb
  • retrolenticular/ retrolentiform portion
  • sublenticular/ sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, while the genu carries the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers.

The retrolenticular part contains the parietopontine, occipitopontine and occipitotectal fibres and the sublenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibres.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with diarrhoea and pellagra-like photosensitive skin eruptions for the last 5 years. Her vital examinations are normal. Urine analysis reveals an increase in the amino acid levels but normal levels of 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid (5-HIAA). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history of a 16-year-old child presenting with diarrhoea and pellagra-like photosensitive skin eruptions with urine analysis showing an increase in the amino acid levels and normal 5-HIAA levels is suggestive of Hartnup disease.

Amino acids are reabsorbed in the kidneys in the proximal convoluted tubule. Aminoaciduria points towards a pathology.

Hartnup disease (pellagra-like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a single defect in the renal and intestinal transport of neutral amino acids (eg, Tryptophan). Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss leads to its reduced bioavailability. This hampers niacin synthesis, and Hartnup disorder can thus present with manifestations of niacin deficiency (pellagra) like diarrhoea, dermatitis, and dementia.

Clinical features:

  • Most of the children are asymptomatic
  • Symptomatic patients show cutaneous photosensitivity
  • The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun, and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash may be pruritic, and chronic eczema may also appear.
  • Some patients may also have intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady, wide-based gait, which usually lasts for a few days and recovers spontaneously.

The diagnosis of Hartnup disorder is established by typical clinical history and the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine.

The Obermeyer test will be positive for Hartnup disorder. The Obermeyer test detects the urinary excretion of indole compounds. Indole derivates such as indican are found in large amounts in patients due to bacterial breakdown of unabsorbed tryptophan in the intestines. 

Urinary excretion of other amino acids remains normal, which differentiates it from causes of generalized aminoaciduria like Fanconi syndrome. 

Treatment:

  • Niacin or niacinamide supplements
  • Nicotinamide for attacks

Other options:

Option A: In Carcinoid syndrome, there is an excess synthesis of serotonin. This consumes available tryptophan and leads to a deficiency of niacin and eventually pellagra-like symptoms. In carcinoid syndrome, excess serotonin is converted to 5-HIAA which is excreted in urine. This patient has normal levels of 5-HIAA.

Option B:  Nutritional pellagra can appear in patients with excessive maize-based diets. Maize has niacin in its unusable form. Additionally, they will not excrete amino acids in urine. 

Option C: Fructosuria will present with fructose in urine instead of amino acids.

questions.text: When does the anterior fontanelle close?
questions.solution:
The anterior fontanelle ideally closes between 18-24 months. However, the closest answer in the given options is 12–24 months of age.

Fontanelle of the skull:

  • The anterior fontanelle is present between the two frontal and two parietal bones. It closes at around 18-24 months. The junction is marked by bregma where the coronal and sagittal sutures meet.
  • The posterior fontanelle is present between the junction of the sagittal and lambdoid suture and closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
  • The sphenoid fontanelle corresponds to the pterion and also closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
  • The mastoid fontanelle closes around at the end of the first year.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. After eating her food in one go, she induces forceful vomiting. Her BMI is 27 kg/m2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting and a BMI of 27 kg/m2, points towards the diagnosis of bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

The weight is normal in most patients with bulimia nervosa. However, few patients may either be overweight or underweight. There is a risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. 

Treatment modalities are cognitive behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and antidepressants such as fluoxetine.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese. These symptoms are usually present for at least a period of 3 months. Associated features can include depression, anxiety, amenorrhea in females, hypothermia, and bradycardia. 

Option C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition where scrupulous individuals are overly concerned that something they thought or did might be a sin or a violation of religious or moral doctrine. The treatment of choice for OCD is cognitive behavioral therapy.

Option D: Binge-eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is characterized by rapid intake of abnormally large quantities of food over a short period of time, even when not hungry. There are feelings of guilt about the eating episodes, but these patients do not compensate in any way following the episodes of binge.

questions.text: In a case of alcohol abuse, which of the following preservatives is used to preserve blood during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride (NaF) (10 mg/ml) and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) can be used to preserve blood during an autopsy.

Sodium Fluoride (NaF) inhibits glycolysis by preventing the breakdown of glucose, which could alter the blood alcohol content. It also has antimicrobial properties to prevent the growth of bacteria and fungi and potassium oxalate acts as an anticoagulant to prevent blood clotting and helps analyse the sample.

A preservative is not necessary if:

  • The viscera can be analysed in 24 hours
  • If the sample can be stored in a refrigerator or icebox
  • Bone, hair, nail specimens
  • Lung for inhaled poisons
  • The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of non-volatile poisons becomes difficult.

In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should also be taken for sampling.

Other options:

  • NaCl (Sodium Chloride): While useful in various laboratory settings, sodium chloride does not prevent glycolysis or microbial growth in blood samples, making it unsuitable for preserving blood for alcohol content analysis.
  • Rectified Spirit: It is a highly concentrated form of ethanol. Adding rectified spirit to a blood sample intended for alcohol analysis would contaminate the sample and invalidate the results.
  • Formalin: Primarily used for preserving tissues by fixing them, formalin is not suitable for preserving blood samples for alcohol analysis, as it can interfere with the chemical assays used to measure ethanol levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is decreased in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Albumin, an acute phase reactant, is decreased in acute inflammation.

Inflammation results in changes in the levels of certain proteins called acute phase reactants (APR). These changes contribute to the body's defense mechanisms and adaptive capabilities. The levels of APR are primarily regulated by cytokines produced during the inflammatory process, such as interleukin-6 (IL-6).

APRs are classified as positive and negative based on whether their levels increase or decrease in inflammatory states respectively. C-reactive protein (CRP), hepcidin, ferritin, serum amyloid A (SAA), fibrinogen, and haptoglobin are positive APRs. Albumin, transferrin, and transthyretin are negative APRs.

APR measurements are not specific to any disease and cannot differentiate between infectious and other causes of inflammation. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is an indirect measure of APR levels, particularly fibrinogen.

questions.text: Identify the chromosomal abnormality from the karyotyping shown below :
questions.solution:
The given karyotype is Trisomy 18- Edward's syndrome.

Edward's syndrome: Trisomy 18 results in Edward’s syndrome, in which a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 is inherited as a result of meiotic nondisjunction. The clinical features include micrognathia, low-set ears, prominent occiput, and rocker bottom feet Prenatal ultrasound reveals fetal growth restriction.

The craniofacial features include dolichocephaly, short palpebral fissures, micrognathia, external anomalies of the ears, and redundant skin at the back of the neck.

Other features include a clenched fist with overriding fingers, i.e. index finger overlapping the third and 5th finger overlapping the 4th, small fingernails, underdeveloped thumbs, short sternum, and club feet.

Heart defects are the most common structural malformations seen in Edwards syndrome. It includes defects of septum, patent ductus arteriosus, valvular defects. Other structural malformations associated with other systems(in decreasing order) are,

  • Renal: Horseshoe kidney
  • GIT: Omphalocele, esophageal atresia with tracheo-oesophageal fistula, pyloric stenosis.
  • CNS: Spina bifida, cerebellar hypoplasia, corpus callosum agenesis
  • Eye: Microphthalmia, cataract, corneal opacities
  • Limb: Radial aplasia/hypoplasia

Other options : 

Option A: Trisomy 13 - Patau Syndrome

  • It is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities.
  • Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent.
  • The midline facial abnormalities that are seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”).
  • Other defects associated with Patau’s syndrome include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows the facial abnormalities seen in Patau syndrome:

Option B: Trisomy 21: Down's Syndrome

  • It is the most common chromosomal abnormality.
  • Children with Down’s syndrome have severe mental retardation, which progressively declines with advancing age.
  • Patients have characteristic facial features that include a flat facial profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and epicanthal folds.
  • There is a horizontal palmar crease, and muscle tone at birth is decreased, which leads to a “floppy baby".

Option D: Trisomy 11 is extremely rare and often leads to miscarriage in early pregnancy.

questions.text: Echocardiography of a patient showed mitral stenosis with vegetation present on the mitral valve. The image of the histopathological study of the vegetation is given below. Identify the finding.
questions.solution:
The image of the histopathological study depicts Aschoff bodies. This feature is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. During acute rheumatic fever, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart. 

Chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening and fibrosis of the valve leaflets, often with calcific deposits. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish mouth appearance (buttonhole).

Other options:

Option B: Ferruginous bodies are histopathologic findings in interstitial lung disease suggestive of asbestosis (significant asbestos exposure).

Option C: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are a histological feature characteristic of malakoplakia which is a rare inflammatory condition that typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals mainly affecting the urinary tract.

Option D: Spider cells are seen in Rhabdomyoma.

questions.text: A family was found dead in a closed room without windows, and smoke coming from a woodfire was present. Which of the following features is likely to be seen on their bodies?
questions.solution:
In the case of a family found dead in a closed room with smoke from a wood fire, there is likely to be cherry red discoloration on their bodies. This discoloration is due to carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which can occur from smoke in an enclosed space.

The colour of postmortem staining in CO poisoning is cherry red. Carbon monoxide is a byproduct of incomplete combustion of organic materials, such as wood. When inhaled, CO binds to hemoglobin in the blood with an affinity approximately 240 times greater than that of oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb). This reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, leading to tissue hypoxia.

The cherry red discolouration is a hallmark of CO poisoning. This occurs because COHb imparts a bright red colour, distinct from the darker hue associated with deoxygenated hemoglobin. 

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discolouration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6–12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in the summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.

questions.text: In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the 'c' wave of JVP?
questions.solution:
In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs between Points B and C is iso-volumetric contraction, which corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP.

In iso-volumetric contraction, the ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents iso-volumetric contraction occurring in ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole.

Calcium binds to calmodulin during smooth muscle contraction.

Increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ binds to and activates calcium-binding proteins (calmodulin, troponin) or activates protein kinases (or phospholipase C) to bring about physiological effects.

Calmodulin is structurally and functionally related to troponin. In place of troponin, smooth muscle cells contain a large amount of the regulatory protein calmodulin; it is different in the manner in which it initiates contraction. Calmodulin initiates contraction by activating the myosin light chain kinase. Troponin, on the other hand, initiates contraction by causing a conformational change in the tropomyosin molecule which then uncovers the active sites on the actin filament.

The sequence of events in smooth muscle contraction:

  • Binding of acetylcholine to muscarinic receptors
  • Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell
  • Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
  • Myosin phosphorylation
  • Increased myosin ATPase activity and binding of myosin to actin

Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle.

Other options :

Option B: Actin is a protein that makes up microfilaments. Microfilaments are present in the outer zone of the cytoplasm and provide support to the cell membrane. In muscle cells, a specialized arrangement of actin provides the mechanism for muscle contraction.

Option C: Myosin is the major contractile protein found in muscle cells. Its specialized arrangement with actin is essential for muscle contraction. It does not play a role in axonal transport. 

Option D: Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by exposure to cotton dust?
questions.solution:
Byssinosis is caused by exposure to cotton dust.

Byssinosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to cotton dust as in textile and rope-making industries. Chest X-ray shows hyperlucency, diaphragmatic flattening, and emphysema. A chest CT demonstrates ground glass opacities largely distributed in the basal regions with centrilobular nodules.

Other options : 

Option A: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. The inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, which accumulate in the connective tissue. Initially, it causes simple coal workers pneumoconiosis with little or no pulmonary dysfunction. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis which is called complicated coal workers' pneumoconiosis. The upper lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Option B: Silicosis is a form of pneumoconiosis which is a cause of permanent disability and mortality. It occurs in people working in sandblasting, pottery, and ceramics industry, mining, and construction work. It occurs due to the inhalation of silica dust. The patient presents with a cough, exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. 

Option D: Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. A thermophilic actinomycete, Thermoactinomyces sacchari is the causative organism. The symptoms are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and fever. Initially, it can result in acute diffuse bronchiolitis, If left untreated it can progress to diffuse fibrosis, emphysema, and bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. He had similar episodes in the past along with steatorrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. Which of the following types of necrosis is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting and similar complaints in the past with steatorrhea, weight loss, and fatigue is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. Fat necrosis is seen in such patients.

Fat necrosis refers to the destruction of fat tissue due to various reasons like injury, surgery, etc. Examples of fat necrosis include pancreatitis, breast trauma, and panniculitis.

In pancreatitis, there is a release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification). Histologic examination reveals foci of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following terms refers to instilling a particular point of view in people’s minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.solution:
The act of instilling a particular point of view in people’s minds and inhibiting their independent thought is referred to as Health propaganda.

When information is used to spread a particular systemized doctrine it is called health propaganda.

The difference between health education (option A) and health propaganda is given below:

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour; Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour The process is behaviour centred  The process is information centred

 

Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach: Governmental intervention, direct or indirect, designed to alter human behavior. It may range from prohibition to imprisonment.
  • Service approach: Providing all health services needed by people at their doorstep on the assumption that people would use them to improve their own health.
  • Health education approach: People must be educated through planned learning experiences on what to do, and be informed, educated, and encouraged to make their own choices for a healthy life.
  • Primary health care approach: Full participation and active involvement in planning and delivery of health services based on principles of primary health care viz community involvement and intersectoral coordination. 

Other options:

Option C: Health awareness is a crucial component of public health strategies aimed at promoting positive health behaviors and reducing the burden of disease through education and preventive measures.

Option D: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention and is the process of enabling people to increase control over and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions, or lifestyle changes.

questions.text: During surgery for patent ductus arteriosus, which anatomical structure is most susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is most susceptible to injury during surgery for patent ductus arteriosus.

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 6th arch artery while the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 4th arch artery. This occurs because the distal portion of the 6th arch disappears on the right side along with the 5th arch artery. Thus the nerve on the right side loops under the 4th arch artery.

The patent ductus arteriosus is due to a defect in the 6th aortic arch, also known as the pulmonary arch, as it gives off a branch to the growing lung bud. On the right side, this arch forms the right pulmonary artery proximally and disappears distally. On the left side, the distal part remains patent to form the ductus arteriosus that shunts blood from the right ventricle to the dorsal aorta. This is obliterated after birth forming the ligamentum arteriosum. If the ductus arteriosus remains patent after birth, it is referred to as patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

A decrease in Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure, and an increase reduces further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors: Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure.
  • Filtration fraction : An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

Other options : 

Option A: Efferent Arteriole Dilation reduces the resistance to blood leaving the glomerulus. This leads to a decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. A reduction in hydrostatic pressure lowers the driving force for filtration, resulting in a decreased GFR.

Option B: Afferent Arteriole Constriction decreases blood flow into the glomerulus. This lowers the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. Lower pressure reduces the filtration rate across the glomerular capillary wall, leading to a decrease in GFR.

Option C: Increase in Glomerular Plasma Flow: If glomerular plasma flow increases but the efferent arteriole doesn't constrict, the extra blood flow is quickly carried away. This prevents a significant rise in the pressure inside the glomerular capillaries. As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) doesn't significantly increase, because the necessary increase in filtration pressure doesn't occur.
