questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for __________________.
questions.solution:
Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. 

Breastfeeding should be started as soon as possible after birth. For an infant to be called exclusively breastfed, pre-lacteal feeds and even water are not to be given. However, giving vitamin drops, if indicated, is included under the definition of exclusive breastfeeding.

Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 months of age. Breastfeeding should be continued for at least the first year and beyond, as long as the mother and child mutually agree.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with swelling at the base of the thumb after falling on an outstretched hand while playing football. Which of the following is most likely to be to be injured?
questions.solution:
The history of falls on the outstretched hand and swelling at the base of the thumb suggests the diagnosis of a scaphoid fracture.

A scaphoid fracture is the most common carpal fracture. Direct axial compression or hyperextension of the wrist, such as with a fall onto an outstretched hand, results in a scaphoid fracture.

Pain is localized to the radial aspect of the wrist proximal to the thumb metacarpal. Swelling may or may not be noticeable. Focal tenderness is usually present in one of three places - the volar prominence at the distal wrist crease, or just distal to Lister's tubercle.

The most common complications include nonunion, avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the proximal fracture segment, and osteoarthritis. 

Diagnostic sign- precisely localized tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. 

X-ray of the wrist is taken but it has a high false-negative rate. Hence empiric splinting or MRI is recommended as the next step in such cases where clinical suspicion exists but X-ray findings are normal. Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a scaphoid cast applied in a glass-holding position. Reduction with compression screw is preferred for displaced fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following channels is defective in a child with a CFTR gene defect?
questions.solution:
A child with a CFTR(Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein) mutation will have cystic fibrosis. Abnormalities in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride (Cl-) channels.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder in children and adults. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion on chromosome 7q. This encodes CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) protein, which is involved in the regulation of Cl- channel. This mutation results in a lack of Cl− secretion and an increase in ENaC-mediated Na+ and water reabsorption.

The defect in the chloride channel results in the production of hyper-viscous, adherent secretions, which can obstruct the airways. This results in a reduced periciliary layer that inhibits the function of the mucociliary escalator and alters the local environment to reduce the effectiveness of antimicrobial secretions. This leads to repeated pulmonary infections, specifically Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which can lead to the destruction of lung parenchyma.

Diagnosis is made by elevated sweat chloride levels. Sweat chloride levels are generally elevated > 60 mEq/L. Normally, Cl- is reabsorbed into the sweat glands from sweat. This is inhibited in cystic fibrosis. Treatment includes chest physiotherapy, postural drainage, short-term antibiotics, and inhaled bronchodilators. Inhaled hypertonic saline helps in mucus clearance. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy can be done in case of pancreatic insufficiency.Drug therapy includes Lumacaftor or Tezacaftor, which help in the correction of misfolded proteins and aid the transport of these proteins to the cell surface. Another drug called Ivacaftor is used, which helps in chloride channel opening.

Lung transplant is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. The patient was diagnosed with hyperammonemia type-1. Which of the following statement is the enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The enzyme defective in hyperammonemia type-1 is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I). 

CPS I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses NH3 and CO2 as substrates to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. It is a mitochondrial enzyme. Its defect leads to hyperammonemia type 1.

The clinical symptoms of urea cycle disorders include vomiting, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, severe mental retardation, hypothermia, and apnea due to high plasma ammonia levels.

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate-limiting enzyme in pyrimidine synthesis. It is inhibited by UTP (uridine triphosphate) and activated by ATP and PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate).

Option C: Ornithine transcarbamoylase combines carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. Deficiency causes elevated glutamine levels in the blood, CSF, and urine.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. During an autopsy, apparent bleeding was seen on the surface of his brain. Which type of hemorrhage would not be washed away under direct running water?
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid haemorrhage will persist when washed under running water during an autopsy.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding in the space between the brain and the arachnoid membrane which is the subarachnoid space. During an autopsy, the blood from a subarachnoid haemorrhage is not easily washed away by running water. This is because it is located in this deep layer, which can trap the blood within the brain's sulci and gyri.

While doing the autopsy, there is typically some fresh blood present. However, it cannot be washed off because the blood is situated beneath the very thin and transparent arachnoid layer.

This makes the blood from a SAH less likely to be displaced compared to haemorrhages located in other regions, such as epidural or subdural spaces. Thus, despite running water during an autopsy, the blood from a subarachnoid haemorrhage often remains in place, making it detectable even after washing.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. The patient's chest radiograph shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates in the perihilar region. Histopathological findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of an HIV patient with a CD4 count of 170/ μL and Gomori’s methenamine silver staining showing crescent-shaped cysts with X-ray findings of symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. The classic radiographic appearance consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Giemsa stain, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains demonstrate trophozoites. The cyst wall appears black with Gomori's methenamine silver stain. Shown below is an image of the Gomori’s methenamine silver staining showing crescent-shaped cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls of P. jirovecii.

Other options:

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

questions.text: A child presents with cleft lip, cleft palate and mental retardation. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
The given findings of cleft lip, cleft palate with mental retardation in a child are consistent with trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome).

Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities. Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent. The midline facial abnormalities seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, mental retardation, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, renal defects, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows some facial features of Patau syndrome:

Other options:

Option A: Prader-Willi syndrome occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. It is characterized by mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet.

Option C: Angelman syndrome is characterized by the deletion of the ubiquitin ligase gene (UBE3A) on maternal chromosome 15q12 and the silencing of the paternal chromosomal counterpart. It is characterized by intellectual disability, microcephaly, ataxic gait, seizures, and inappropriate laughter. Due to inappropriate laughter and ataxia, they are also known as happy puppets.

Option D: Trisomy 18 or Edwards syndrome is characterized by mental retardation, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers: the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. It is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis methods is used to detect monkeypox virus?
questions.solution:
Real-time PCR is used to detect monkeypox virus which contains enveloped double-stranded DNA.

Real-time PCR helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)

Other types of PCR:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Multiplex PCR: Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained.
  • Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. 

Other options

Option A: Sanger's technique was the first technique used to determine the sequence of proteins. The first protein to be sequenced by this method was insulin. Sanger’s reagent is 1- Flouro 2,4 Dinitro benzene. Only dipeptides and tripeptides can be sequenced by this method.

Option B:  Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

Option C: ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) involves the use of an immunosorbent, which is an absorbing material that is specific for one of the components of the reaction, either the antigen or antibody.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a resting tremor in his right hand, stiffness in his arms, and slow movements. On examination, he exhibits a shuffling gait and reduced arm swing while walking. Which of the following pathways is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:

This pathway plays a crucial role in regulating voluntary movement by modulating the activity of the basal ganglia. Dysfunction of the nigrostriatal pathway disrupts the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine, contributing to the characteristic motor symptoms observed in Parkinson's disease.

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with umbilical hernia,  dry, rough skin, rough hair, and macroglossia is suggestive of Cretinism.

Cretinism is congenital hypothyroidism, which is one of the most common preventable causes of intellectual disability.

Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological or myxedematous cretinism. 

Newborn screening by measuring TSH in blood samples obtained by heelprick between 1 and 5 days of life is the most important method of diagnosis. Levothyroxine given orally is the treatment for congenital hypothyroidism.

Total serum T4 or free T4 levels and TSH should be monitored every 1-2 months in the first 6 months of life, and then every 2-4 months between 6 months and 3 years of age, to ensure treatment efficacy.

Other options : 

Option A: Galactosemia: Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain. Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive.

Option B - Edward syndrome is trisomy 18. It is characterised by low birth weight, prominent occiput, rocker-bottom feet, intellectual disability, and cardiac and renal malformations.

Option C - Prader-Willi syndrome is caused due to genomic imprinting, where there is the deletion of a part of the paternal chromosome 15. The clinical features include hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, dysmorphic facial features, delayed puberty, and behavioural problems.

questions.text: Inability to recognize familiar faces is known as?
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces

In humans, storage and recognition of faces is more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals, though the left lobe is also active. Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia, the inability to recognize faces.

Patients with this abnormality can recognize forms and reproduce them. They can recognize people by their voices, and many of them show autonomic responses when they see familiar as opposed to unfamiliar faces. However, they cannot identify the familiar faces they see. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the role of the right hemisphere is primary.

questions.text: According to the MTP Act, termination of pregnancy due to contraceptive failure can be done up to what period of gestation?
questions.solution:
According to the MTP Act, termination of pregnancy due to contraception failure can be done up to 20 weeks of gestation.

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of an obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state.

Consent:

Only the patient's consent is required for MTP; her partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 years or if the patient is mentally ill.

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint be lodged with the police.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with diarrhoea for a few weeks. His family members report observing abnormal behaviour that they had not noticed earlier. Recently, he has developed a rash around his neck, as shown below. This rash flares up when exposed to sunlight. Which of the following supplements is most likely to benefit the patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhoea, abnormal behaviour (probably dementia) and rash around his neck (casal's neck) points to a diagnosis of pellagra which is secondary to nicotinamide/ niacin/ vitamin B3 deficiency. Hence this patient will benefit from nicotinamide supplements.

Niacin deficiency is mostly seen among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which are low in niacin and tryptophan. Excess leucine in jowar and maize disrupts the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

Niacin can be synthesized in the body from tryptophan. Two compounds, nicotinic acid and nicotinamide, have the biological activity of niacin. The nicotinamide ring of the coenzymes nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) participate in oxidation/reduction reactions.

The initial symptoms of pellagra include loss of appetite, generalized weakness, irritability, abdominal pain, and vomiting. This is followed by bright red glossitis (beefy tongue) and a characteristic pigmented, scaly skin rash in sun-exposed areas. This rash is known as Casal’s necklace when it forms a ring around the neck. 

The 4 D's of pellagra are Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and if untreated, Death.

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone. It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

questions.text: What does the term "tracking" refer to in relation to blood pressure?

choices.text: Observing changes in blood pressure throughout a 24-hour period
Recording and analyzing blood pressure levels over an extended period to identify patterns and predict future readings
Comparing blood pressure values between different populations based on demographics
Assessing blood pressure during exercise to evaluate cardiovascular health

questions.solution:
"Tracking" in relation to blood pressure refers to recording and analyzing blood pressure levels over an extended period to identify patterns and predict future readings.

When blood pressure levels are observed from childhood through to adulthood, individuals with higher blood pressure early on typically maintain higher levels, while those with lower levels tend to stay lower as they age. This consistent ranking of blood pressure over time is called "tracking." This helps identify children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have been identified, whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On eliciting further history, it was confirmed that proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema. On examination, damage to the abducens nerve was noted. Which of the following ocular movements will be impaired?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with recurrent episodes of headache and pain over the medial canthus and repeated use of nasal decongestants, suggests that the patient was suffering from sinusitis, which has most likely resulted in cavernous sinus thrombosis, and the injury of the abducens nerve will affect the lateral ocular movement as it supplies the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves.

In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through the intercavernous communication. Also, cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache.
On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Within the cavernous sinus are the abducens nerve and the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery.

Image showing cavernous sinus and the structures related to it.

Orbital apex syndrome is a condition similar to cavernous sinus syndrome with retro-orbital pain and involvement of 2,3,4,5 and 6 cranial nerves. The differentiating feature is the optic nerve involvement leading to early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertriglyceridemia was prescribed statins to help stabilize his levels. Despite taking statins, the levels remained elevated at around 600 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs can be added to help lower his triglyceride levels?
questions.solution:
In this case of a 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertriglyceridemia who was prescribed statins for his elevated triglyceride levels and still had elevated triglyceride levels, gemfibrozil can be given to help lower his triglyceride levels.

Gemfibrozil belongs to the fibrate group of drugs that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARα), which stimulate fatty acid oxidation, reduce the expression of apo C-III (inhibitor of lipolysis), and thereby reduce triglyceride levels.

Gemfibrozil is a first-line drug for patients with markedly raised triglyceride levels. Episodes of acute pancreatitis are prevented in patients with chylomicronaemia and severe hypertriglyceridemia. It is most effective in type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

Other options:

Option C: Cholestyramines are bile acid-binding resins and they increase the excretion of bile acids. This results in increased conversion of cholesterol mobile acids by the liver.

Option D: Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal sterol absorption, reduces LDL cholesterol, minimal increase in HDL level and also decreases the absorption of phytosterols.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ?
questions.solution:
Thymus and bone marrow are the primary lymphoid organs (also known as central lymphoid organs). It is the place where immature lymphocytes develop, differentiate, proliferate, and mature into immune competent cells. 

A secondary lymphoid organ (also known as a peripheral lymphoid organ) is where the antigen is localized so that it can be effectively exposed to mature lymphocytes. These include the spleen, lymph nodes, tonsils, sppendix, and Peyer’s patches.

Both B lymphocytes and T lymphocytes are produced in the bone marrow. B lymphocytes also mature in bone marrow, while T lymphocytes mature in Thymus.

Given below is the histopathological image of the thymus.

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of the distribution that falls within one standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
According to the empirical rule of normal distributions, 68% of the distribution falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean.

In a normal curve, the area on either side of the mean will include :

Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.

  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.

questions.text: Following the death of a person, his family who lived abroad was unable to reach him, and hence his body needed to be preserved. Which of the following substances can typically be detected in his body, even if the person did not consume the substance shortly before death?
questions.solution:
Alcohol can normally be detected in visceral organs, even if the person did not consume the substance shortly before death.

After death, the body undergoes various biological processes, including putrefaction. During putrefaction, bacteria present in the gastrointestinal tract and other tissues can ferment carbohydrates, leading to the production of alcohol. 

Therefore, the presence of alcohol in visceral organs during an autopsy can sometimes be attributed to postmortem production rather than recent ingestion.

Other options :

Aconite, arsenic, and morphine are not naturally produced by the body or formed after death. These substances must be ingested or administered. Aconite and morphine would only be detected if consumed before death, and arsenic needs prior exposure to be present in the body. Finding these substances in the body indicates pre-death exposure, unlike alcohol, which can sometimes be produced after death.

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic patient presents with altered sensorium and confusion. He also complains of weakness in both lower limbs and occasional tingling in his legs. His staple diet includes white polished rice. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 54-year-old chronic alcoholic, who consumes polished rice as a staple diet, and presents with altered sensorium and tingling sensation (neuritis), points to the diagnosis of Beri-beri. 

The vitamin deficiency associated with this condition is thiamine (vitamin B1). It is commonly seen in people who consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

The two principal deficiency diseases of thiamine are:

Dry beri-beri is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, edema.

Thiamine deficiency can also be named based on the pattern of dietary deficiency seen. These include oriental beri-beri (diet predominantly including polished rice) and occidental Beri-beri (a diet rich in refined flours and food fads). The latter form is commonly seen in alcoholics. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke's encephalopathy in adults.

High-risk groups for thiamine deficiency are:

  • Lactating mothers
  • Patients on regular haemodialysis
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Prolonged gastric aspiration
  • People who go on long fasts
  • High-risk groups should be treated with direct supplementation of thiamine.

Other options: 

Option A: Phrynoderma is a form of asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic follicular hyperkeratosis, where follicular papules of various sizes with central keratotic plugs that block the follicle openings develop on the skin.

Option C: Pellagra will classically present with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia in a predominantly maize-consuming population, not with neuritis in an alcoholic patient consuming white polished rice.

Option D: Eczema is inflammation of the skin seen in a variety of skin conditions.Eczema. It is characterized by itching, dryness, erythema, fissuring, hyperkeratosis, lichenification, scaling, and vesiculation of the affected areas.

questions.text: Which of the following structures will be present in the area marked below?
questions.solution:
The pterygopalatine ganglion will be present in the area marked in the image above which is the pterygopalatine fossa.

The pterygopalatine ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion located in the pterygopalatine fossa, a small, cone-shaped depression situated deep in the skull. This fossa is located posterior to the maxilla (upper jaw) and adjacent to the nasal cavity.

It is responsible for parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal gland, nasal glands, and palatine glands. Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers originate from the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and travel through the greater petrosal nerve. These fibres join with the deep petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal before synapsing in the ganglion.

Boundaries of the Pterygopalatine Fossa:

  • Anteriorly: Posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posteriorly: Pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone.
  • Medially: Perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.
  • Laterally: Pterygomaxillary fissure, which opens into the infratemporal fossa.
  • Superiorly: Inferior surface of the sphenoid bone.
  • Inferiorly: Palatine bone.

Structures surrounding the Pterygopalatine Ganglion:

  • Maxillary Nerve (V2): A branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) that passes through the fossa, giving off branches to the ganglion.
  • Greater and Lesser Palatine Nerves: Emerge from the ganglion to innervate the hard and soft palate.
  • Nasal Nerves: Branches that innervate the nasal cavity, including the nasopalatine nerve.
  • Pharyngeal Nerve: Provides innervation to parts of the nasopharynx.
  • Arterial Supply: The maxillary artery's branches, including the sphenopalatine artery, which supplies the nasal cavity, are present in the fossa.
    Foramina and fissures:
  • Foramen rotundum: Transmits the maxillary nerve (V2) into the fossa.
  • Pterygoid Canal: Contains the nerve of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve), which carries both sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers.
  • Sphenopalatine Foramen: Connects the fossa to the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A patient presents with an inability to shrug his shoulders after a fall from the stairs. On examination, an injury to the posterior triangle of his neck is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is unable to shrug his shoulders due to an injury to the spinal accessory nerve, which is present in the posterior triangle of the neck and supplies the trapezius muscle.

The spinal accessory nerve innervates the sternocleidomastoid just before entering the posterior triangle. 

  • If the nerve is injured before it enters the posterior triangle, actions of the sternocleidomastoid will be affected.
  • If the nerve is injured within the posterior triangle, the sternocleidomastoid will be spared.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes: 

  • Retraction of scapula
  • Shrugging of the shoulder
  • Overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior)

Paralysis of the trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent).

questions.text: A 14-day-old baby is being evaluated in the pediatric department for ambiguous genitalia. On examination, the baby is dehydrated. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Karyotyping evaluation demonstrates  46, XX chromosomal pattern. Measurement of which of the following will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (classical 21-hydroxylase deficiency). Measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis in this case.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders associated with the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Children usually present with salt-wasting crises as seconded by dehydration with hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

The diagnosis is confirmed by markedly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. The most commonly performed neonatal screening programs screen only for 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in dried blood obtained by heel stick and absorbed on filter paper cards. Also, these same cards are screened in parallel for other congenital conditions, such as hypothyroidism and phenylketonuria.

Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment. Patients with salt-wasting and virilizing forms are treated with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone. Surgical treatment is usually done between 2-6 months of age for significantly virilized females.

Males with 21-hydroxylase deficiency who have had inadequate corticosteroid therapy may develop testicular adrenal rest tumors. These usually regress following increased steroid dosage.

The image below summarizes the pathway involved in steroid hormonal production and the pearl summarizes the various non-classical forms of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. 

Note:  In congenital adrenal hyperplasia, as a result of the deficient enzyme(21-hydroxylase), there is an impaired conversion of 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycortisol. This results in the overproduction of adrenal androgen precursors and adrenal androgens. The diagnostic hormone 17-hydroxyprogesterone is markedly elevated in CAH. If the 17-hydroxyprogesterone level is markedly elevated (>10,000 ng/dL), the diagnosis of classic CAH is likely, whereas levels >2000 ng/dL but <10,000 ng/dL typically reflect non-classic disease.

Other options:

Option A: Although 21-hydroxylase is the deficient enzyme in this condition. Its level is not routinely measured to confirm the diagnosis.

Options C and D: 17-hydroxylase and 11β hydroxylase deficiency generally present with salt retention crises and hypertension.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with lethargy. On examination, the child is unresponsive, unable to take oral feeds, eyes dry and sunken, and severely malnourished. What is the fluid of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
A child with features of severe dehydration like sunken dry eyes, lethargy and being unable to take oral feeds must be started on IV fluid correction for dehydration. Since the child has severe malnutrition as well, the fluid of choice is ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose.

  • Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose
  • Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose 
  • Half-strength Darrow solution with 5% dextrose.

Children are given a total of 100 ml/kg of fluid for severe dehydration. Children below 1 year of age are administered that amount over 6 hours. Children over 1 year of age are given that amount over 3 hours.

The treatment of some dehydration in a child with severe acute malnutrition is half-strength WHO low-osmolarity ORS with glucose and potassium.

ReSoMal is another oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centres for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains a higher amount of glucose (125mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man came with complaints of fever and chills since the last one week. On examination, tachycardia and low BP are present. Peripheral smear findings are given below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of fever with chills and the peripheral smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria shows a very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by other plasmodia. After the ring forms in the peripheral blood, the rest of the erythrocytic cycle occurs in the capillaries of the brain and internal organs. So, only ring forms can be seen in the peripheral blood and not the late trophozoites and schizonts. The gametocytes of P. falciparum are crescent-shaped or “banana-shaped” (as shown below), whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant tertian malaria. This means that the fever has a periodicity of 48 hours corresponding to one cycle of erythrocytic schizogony. Malignant because it is a more severe and fatal type of malaria.

Major manifestations of severe falciparum malaria include unarousable coma/ cerebral malaria (failure to localize or respond appropriately to stimuli or coma persisting for >30 min after generalized convulsion), acidosis, severe normocytic normochromic anemia, renal failure, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Other manifestations include hemoglobinuria, hyperparasitemia, jaundice, and extreme weakness.

The treatment of choice is artesunate given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary.

In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be done for measuring long-term glucose control in patients with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
In patients with diabetes mellitus, HbA1c is the best method to measure long-term glucose control.

Glycated hemoglobin, reported as HbA1c, has been used to monitor glycemic control in patients with diabetes for many years. HbA1c results from the attachment of glucose to the N-terminal valine of the hemoglobin β-chain.

The concentration of HbA1c depends on both the glucose concentration in the blood and the lifespan of the erythrocyte. Since the half-life of an RBC is 60 days, the glycated hemoglobin level reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6 to 8 weeks. Normal glucose tolerance is characterized by an HbA1c < 5.7%; any value of HbA1c equal to or exceeding 6.5 % is diagnostic of the patient being diabetic. 

Other options:

Fasting blood sugar, random blood sugar, and urine sugar reflect the status of blood glucose level at the instantaneous moment.

questions.text: What is the level of prevention when a person receives penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Receiving penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease is Secondary prevention.

Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Levels of Prevention : 

1. Primordial prevention:

  • Involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.
  • Examples include adult health problems like obesity and hypertension, which have an early onset due to lifestyles like smoking, eating patterns and physical exercise, which are discouraged from early childhood
  • The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

2. Primary prevention:

  • These are defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''
  • It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem
  • Primary prevention is accomplished by measures promoting general health and well-being, and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures.
  • They include two strategies:
  • Population (mass) strategy: Where the target group is the whole population
  • High-risk strategy: Where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease
  • Examples: immunity, sanitation, and protection of food.

3. Secondary prevention :

  • This is defined as "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.".
  • The specific interventions are early diagnoses like screening tests and adequate treatment.
  • The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process.
  • Secondary prevention is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.
  • It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention.

4. Tertiary prevention :

  • Measures to reduce the duration of mental illness and family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption.
  • Disability limitation belongs to tertiary prevention.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of inhibin?
questions.solution:
Inhibin acts by inhibiting the production of FSH.

The inhibins are produced by the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle, as well as other tissues, including the pituitary, the brain, the adrenal gland, the kidney, the bone marrow, the corpus luteum, and the placenta. Inhibin A is produced by the corpus luteum whereas inhibin B is mainly produced by granulosa cells of the follicle.

FSH specifically stimulates the granulosa cells to produce inhibins. It stimulates inhibin production by the Sertoli cells. This inhibin inhibits FSH production by directly acting on the anterior pituitary. 

Just before ovulation, after the granulosa cells acquire LH receptors, LH also stimulates the production of inhibin by granulosa cells. LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH. Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus.

questions.text: Which of the following post-translational modifications (PTM) is associated with the synthesis of haemoglobin, collagen and immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Haemoglobin, collagen, and immunoglobin are proteins that are synthesized as subunits and undergo subunit aggregation during post-translational modifications (PTM). 

Adult haemoglobin is synthesized separately as 2 alpha chains and 2 beta chains and then aggregated together to form (α2β2) chains.

Collagen is synthesized as pre-procollagen inside cells and released as tropocollagen which aggregates into collagen fibrils through covalent bonds.

Immunoglobulins are components of the immune system and are divided into 5 classes. However, each immunoglobulin has two heavy chains and two light chains synthesized separately and then aggregated. 

Post-translational modifications of the polypeptide chain include the removal of N- or C- polypeptides from zymogens to make mature proteins e.g. trypsinogen to trypsin. Also, covalent alterations of proteins in the form of phosphorylation, glycosylation, etc are considered post-translational modifications.

Subunit aggregation is an essential step that provides functional properties to the structural proteins. Error in aggregation can lead to disease pathologies like Amyloidosis-including ALS, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and prion disease.

Other options:

Options A and C: Gene splicing and alternate splicing are post-transcriptional modifications occurring in mRNA. 

Option D: DNA mismatch repair is a post-replication step.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely?
questions.solution:
Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue, generally occurs after the third decade of life, and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs are pathognomonic. Other findings include degeneration of the intervertebral discs, followed by disc calcification and eventually fusion of the vertebral bodies. Osteophyte formation and calcification of the intervertebral ligaments also occur.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive. The blackening of urine occurs due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

Image A - Normal urine
Image B - Alkaptonuria

Other options:

Option A: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disorder resulting from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. It does not lead to black urine. Patients with PKU have a musty or mousy odor due to phenylacetic acid accumulation.

Option C: Homocystinuria is an inborn error of methionine metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase. It is characterized by tall stature, long limbs, dislocation of the lens of the eye, and predisposition to thromboembolism, but it does not lead to black urine.

Option D: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase. It does not cause black urine. Patients with MSUD have urine with a characteristic sweet odor, resembling maple syrup.

questions.text: Which of the following ion channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is oxygen-sensitive?
questions.solution:
Potassium channels in the peripheral chemoreceptors are oxygen-sensitive. 

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels, whose conductance is reduced in proportion to the degree of hypoxia.

This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ inﬂux. 

Hypoxia induces vasoconstriction by inhibition of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels in pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cell membranes. This leads to depolarization of the cell membrane and activation of calcium channels causing the influx of calcium ions. The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings and constriction of small arteries and arterioles.

When the concentration of O2 in the alveoli decreases below normal the adjacent blood vessels constrict. This effect is opposite to the effect observed in systemic vessels, which dilate rather than constrict in response to low O2 levels.

This is because the low oxygen concentrations can :

  • Stimulate the release of or increase sensitivity to vasoconstrictor substances such as endothelin or reactive oxygen species.
  • Decrease the release of vasodilators such as nitric oxide from the lung.

questions.text: A gym owner noticed that people who come to the gym also drink iced tea. He concluded that drinking iced tea is the sole reason to lose weight. What is this relationship called?
questions.solution:
In the gym owner's case, concluding that iced tea alone causes weight loss is a spurious relationship because it ignores other key factors like exercise and overall diet.

A spurious relationship is when two variables appear to be connected but are actually linked by another factor or are coincidental. In this scenario, the gym owner observed that gym-goers also drink iced tea and concluded that iced tea is the sole cause of weight loss. However, this conclusion is just coincidental because it ignores other important factors, such as exercise, diet, and lifestyle changes, which likely contribute to weight loss.

An association can be broadly grouped under three headings:

  • Spurious association
  • Indirect association
  • Direct (causal) association: One-to-one causal association and Multifactorial causation

Option B: Direct (causal) association: Two variables are stated to be causally related (AB) if a change in A is followed by a change in B. When factor A is present, disease B must result. Measles is one such disease in which such a relation exists.

Option C: Indirect association: The indirect association is an association between a variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable. For example, endemic goitre is generally found in high altitudes, thereby showing an association between altitude and endemic goitre. But, endemic goitre is not due to altitude but due to an environmental deficiency of iodine. Thus, a common factor (i.e., iodine deficiency) can result in an apparent association between two variables, when no association exists. 

Option D: Multifactorial causation is seen in non-communicable diseases or conditions (e.g., Coronary heart disease) where the etiology is multifactorial.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor was found dead in his apartment, and his body had undergone advanced stages of decomposition. Which of the following methods can be used to identify him a week later?
questions.solution:
DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a deceased person whose body has undergone advanced decomposition. 

DNA profiling can also aid in identifying skeletonized or severely decomposed human remains. This process typically involves comparing the genetic profile from the remains with reference samples from relatives, often the victim's parents.

DNA profiling, also known as genetic fingerprinting, is a forensic method used to identify individuals based on their unique genetic makeup, is precise and has high specificity. While decomposition can damage biological tissues, DNA can often be recovered from highly decomposed bodies. DNA can be extracted from bones, teeth, or preserved tissue samples.

In contrast, other methods like visual identification (face recognition), fingerprint analysis, or dental records may be compromised or unfeasible when a body is in an advanced state of decomposition, making DNA profiling the preferred and most reliable choice for identification in such scenarios.

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 live births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8–28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 49.38 per 1000 live births.

Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year

In this population, there were 4050 live births.

NMR = (50+150) x 1000/4050 = 100/2 = 49.38

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are birth asphyxia (leading cause), preterm complications, intrapartum related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is about 25 per 1000 live births.

questions.text:
Match the following genetic diseases with their respective trinucleotide repeat sequences.

          Genetic disease                Trinucleotide repeats

  1. Huntington’s disease               a. CGG
  2. Myotonic dystrophy                 b. GAA
  3. Friedreich ataxia                       c. CAG
  4. Fragile X syndrome                  d. CTG
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1 - c, 2 - d, 3 - b, 4 - a.

1. Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat (>40) expansion mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (second to the third decade) if inherited from the father. Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen.  Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea.

2. Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet repeat expansion of DNA in the DMPK gene. The polynucleotide sequence involved in the expansion is the CTG sequence. This leads to an abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase. In the childhood form of DM,intellectual disability and behavioural problems are often the predominant features. Other key findings of classic DM include, Myotonia or delay in muscle relaxation, weakness and atrophy of facial and distal limb musculature, cardiac abnormalities including cardiomyopathy and conduction disturbances, frontal hair loss, cataracts, insulin resistance.

3.  Friedreich ataxia is the most common inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive cause of spinocerebellar degeneration, caused by the expansion of GAA trinucleotides on chromosome 9. Most patients have pes cavus.

4. Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It occurs due to CGG repeats in the untranslated regions(UTR) of the FMR1 gene.

questions.text: Which of the following has been banned by the Honourable Supreme Court of India for being infamous among doctors in sexual assault cases?
questions.solution:
The two-finger test has been banned by the Honourable Supreme Court of India due to its controversial and problematic nature in sexual assault cases. This test, used to assess a victim's sexual history and physical condition, was deemed unethical and unreliable and was criticised for being invasive and degrading, often failing to provide accurate evidence while infringing on the dignity of the survivor.

The Supreme Court's decision aimed to protect the rights of victims and ensure that forensic examinations in sexual assault cases adhere to ethical and scientific standards.

questions.text: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis, also known as Duhring’s disease is an auto-immune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla. This condition is closely associated with celiac disease (gluten-sensitive enteropathy). 

The clinical manifestations include grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, and scalp with symmetrical distribution and are associated with intense pruritus. 

The characteristic histopathology finding is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils, which is shown in the image below: 

The image below shows dermatitis herpetiformis on the knee.

Dermatitis herpetiformis targets epidermal transglutaminase 3. Direct immunofluorescence shows focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips.

A gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment, but it takes months to years to show clinical improvement. Hence, dapsone is used for short-term management in these patients.

Other Options:

Options A & D: Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease are chronic inflammatory bowel diseases that are mainly idiopathic with a weak genetic component. The common cutaneous manifestations include erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum, psoriasis, aphthous stomatitis, and cutaneous vasculitis.

 Options B: Whipple's disease is a chronic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei, classically presents as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, intermittent fever, weight loss, and arthralgia/arthritis with neurological and cardiological involvement. The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

questions.text: Morbidity of a disease is on the rise. Which of the following statements is correct with respect to this?

choices.text: Incidence will increase and prevalence will decrease
Incidence and prevalence are not related to it
Incidence will decrease and prevalence will increase

questions.solution:
The incidence and prevalence will increase when the morbidity increases.

Morbidity refers to any deviation, whether subjective or objective, from a state of physical well-being. It encompasses conditions such as sickness, illness, and disability. Morbidity is typically measured by morbidity rates or ratios, which include frequency, duration, and severity. Disease frequency is indicated by incidence and prevalence rates.

Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a disease that occur in a population during a specific time period, while prevalence represents the total number of cases, both new and existing, in a population at a given time. Additionally, the average duration of illness, represented by the disability rate, and the severity of illnesses, indicated by the case fatality rate, are also used as measures.

As morbidity increases in a population, both incidence and prevalence rates tend to rise. This is because a higher morbidity indicates a greater number of people experiencing illness (increased incidence) and a larger number of existing cases (increased prevalence). The increased duration of illness (disability days) and the severity of conditions also contribute to the overall morbidity burden.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Crude death rate = ( Number of deaths during the year/Mid year population ) x 1000

Age specific death rate = ( Number of deaths in specific age groups/Mid year population of that age group ) x 1000

Sex specific death rate = ( Number of deaths per year of that sex/Mid year population of that sex ) x 1000

Case fatality rate = ( Total number of deaths due to a particular disease/Total number of cases due to same disease ) x 100

Proportional mortality from a particular disease = ( Number of deaths from a specific disease in a year/ Total deaths from all causes in a year ) x 100

Under 5 mortality rate = ( Number of deaths under 5 yrs of age in a year/Total live birth in that year ) x 1000

Survival rate = ( Total number of patients alive after 5 yrs /Total number of patients diagnosed or treated ) x 100

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding stage (stage 2). 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rates and death rates within a population, leading to changes in population size and age structure.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following processes is mediated by CRISPR CAS-9 technology?
questions.solution:
CRISPR CAS-9 technology mediates the process of gene editing.

CRISPR is Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats

  • CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material.
  • CRISPRs are transcribed into an RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 to a sequence, leading to its cleavage.
  • Gene editing uses an artificial guide RNA that binds Cas9 and is complementary to a DNA sequence of interest and Cas9 induces the break of double-stranded DNA.

One of the first successful diseases used on an experimental basis is sickle cell anemia.

Other gene editing tools are:

  • Zinc-finger nucleases (ZNFs)
  • Transcription-Activator Like Effector Nucleases (TALEN)
  • Meganucleases

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna "for the development of the CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: The dose-response curve (DRC) is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B.  What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.

In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

Other Options:

Option B: In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

Option C: In competitive agonism, the curve shifts to the left.

Option D: In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor, also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has dual activity against hepatitis B and HIV both?
questions.solution:
Tenofovir is an acyclic nucleotide analog used in the treatment of hepatitis B and HIV.

The preferred first-line regimen for managing HIV-1 and hepatitis B co-infection is tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir.

Tenofovir is an acyclic nucleotide analog that is used as first-line therapy for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B and lamivudine-resistant chronic hepatitis B. It is also a potent antiretroviral agent used in the treatment of HIV infection.

In patients with hepatitis B, tenofovir is more potent at suppressing HBV DNA and is active against both wild-type and lamivudine-resistant HBV. It is given as an oral once-daily dose of 300 mg for 48 weeks. Tenofovir therapy provides histologic improvement, reduction in fibrosis score, and regression of cirrhosis in patients. Side effects include acute renal failure and low blood phosphate levels.

Tenofovir, an Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) is used to treat HIV by inhibiting the reverse transcriptase enzyme. It converts to tenofovir diphosphate in cells, competing with dATP to incorporate into viral DNA. This causes chain termination due to the absence of a 3'-hydroxyl group, halting viral DNA synthesis and reducing replication. 

Other options : 

Option B: Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). Nevirapine PLUS twice-daily zidovudine for six weeks, followed by an additional six weeks of the same combination regimen or nevirapine alone is recommended for High-risk infants with mothers who are:

  • HIV positive not on ART
  • Mother diagnosed with HIV 72 hours after delivery.
  • On ART with viral load > 1000 copies/mL
  • With unknown viral load, hasn't been on ART for >4 consecutive weeks.

Option C: Abacavir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) approved for the treatment of HIV-1 infectionThe most serious adverse effect is a hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, malaise, and fatigue.

Option D: Enfuvirtide is an entry (fusion) inhibitor that binds to the transmembrane gp41 of HIV-1 and blocks its entry into the host cells. It is the only approved parenteral antiretroviral drug, and therefore, injection-site reactions like pain, erythema, induration, and nodules/cysts development are most frequently seen.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a phobic disorder. Which of the following defense mechanisms is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Displacement is the defense mechanism in phobias. It is the shifting of emotions about one object/individual onto another object/individual.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

 

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.
Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.
Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the haematologist with complaints of weakness and fatigue. Lab investigations reveal a decrease in the haemoglobin and reticulocyte count while WBC and platelet counts are normal. Bone marrow shows a selective decrease in the erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with lab investigations showing a decrease in haemoglobin and reticulocyte count, normal WBC, and platelet count with a selective decrease in the erythroid precursors are suggestive of pure red cell aplasia.

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a primary marrow disorder that causes the suppression of erythroid progenitors only. One cause is acute parvovirus B19 infection which may lead to an aplastic crisis in patients who already had underlying hemolytic anemia. The hallmark of PRCA, in an otherwise normal marrow, is the absence of erythroblasts.

Causes of pure red cell aplasia include:

  • Neoplasms - thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia
  • Drug exposure - phenytoin, azathioprine, and isoniazid
  • Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin
  • Parvovirus infection
  • Hereditary - Diamond Blackfan syndrome

Patients typically present with symptoms of severe anemia such as fatigue, pallor, and dyspnea. Complete blood count (CBC) shows normocytic or macrocytic anemia with very low reticulocyte count. Bone marrow examination reveals normal cellularity but with a marked reduction or absence of erythroid precursors. Flow cytometry and immunophenotyping can be useful in diagnosing associated conditions such as thymoma or lymphoproliferative disorders.

Immunosuppressive therapy is the mainstay for idiopathic PRCA, including agents like cyclosporine, corticosteroids, and antithymocyte globulin (ATG). For PRCA associated with parvovirus B19, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used.

Other options:

Option A: Megaloblastic anemia is caused by folate or vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia). Peripheral smear shows characteristic macro-ovalocytic red cells that appear hyperchromic, hypersegmented nuclei in neutrophils, and reticulocytopenia. Marrow is markedly hypercellular due to an increase in the number of hematopoietic precursors.

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. Peripheral smears show microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. Bone marrow shows an increase in erythroid progenitors. A significant diagnostic finding is an absence of stainable iron in macrophages which is assessed by Prussian blue stain on aspirated marrow smears.

Option C: Aplastic anemia is a chronic primary hematological failure that results in pancytopenia. Clinically, the patients present with features of pancytopenia such as fatigue, recurrent infections, and petechiae and ecchymoses. Characteristically, splenomegaly will be absent.

A peripheral smear will show reticulocytopenia. Bone marrow aspirates often give a 'dry tap' which means that they yield little material. Thus, a marrow biopsy would show a markedly hypocellular marrow that is devoid of hematopoietic cells (some fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes or plasma cells remain).

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is most likely to be seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is associated with hypokalemic hypochloremic alkalosis.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e. hypokalemia  hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Persistent vomiting secondary to gastric outlet obstruction results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.

The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS):

It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 3 and 6 weeks of age. It is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. 

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right (not from right to left), followed by projectile vomiting.

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis is a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Management includes the correction of metabolic abnormality before the correction of the pylorus. The hypertrophic pylorus is surgically corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy.
