questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days, and she prefers sitting in a dark room during the attacks. She also gives a history of a myocardial infarction 2 years ago. Which of the following drugs cannot be prescribed to this patient to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute attack of migraine. Sumatriptan is contraindicated in a patient with a history of myocardial infarction.

Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists. They are indicated in the management of acute attacks of migraine. They act by arresting the nociceptive nerve signalling in the trigeminovascular system. They also act by vasoconstricting, not only the intracranial vessels but other vessels too. Hence it is contraindicated in patients with a history of ischemic or vasospastic coronary artery disease (history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks), cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease, hemiplegic or basilar migraines, or ischemic bowel diseases. Triptans are also contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches and is seen more commonly in women. It presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. The release of vasoactive peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) by the trigeminal nucleus cells is the theory used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. The neurotransmitters serotonin and dopamine also play a part.

A migraine attack has four phases: premonitory (prodrome), aura, headache, and postdrome; each has distinct and sometimes disabling symptoms, which may overlap.

Migraine can broadly be classified into:

  • Migraine without aura (70-80%): Common migraine.
  • Migraine with aura (20-30%): Classic migraine.

The migraine disability assessment score (MIDAS) can be used to assess the severity of the condition. Avoidance of recognized triggers is helpful to avoid symptoms. The various drugs used to treat an acute attack of migraine are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), triptans, CGRP Receptor Antagonists (rimegepant), 5-HT1/F receptor agonists (lasmiditan), and dopamine receptor antagonists (domperidone). 

The various FDA-approved drugs used in prophylaxis include propranolol, valproate, topiramate, and flunarizine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with tingling and numbness of hands and feet. He also complains of fatigue and constant pain in his lower limbs. Careful history taking reveals episodes of confusion. Blood investigations reveal anaemia and monoclonal spike.  A radiograph of his femur is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes polyneuropathy, symptoms of hypercalcemia (fatigue, confusion), anaemia and monoclonal spike with image showing lytic lesions in the bone.  All these features are suggestive of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myelomas: Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:

  • Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
  • Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
  • Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years

Signs and symptoms

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
  • Renal failure
  • Anemia
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Other options:

Option A- Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia usually occurs in older adults in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (B cell neoplasm). The tumor cells undergo terminal differentiation to plasma cells which secrete monoclonal IgM that causes hyperviscocity syndrome. In this syndrome, light chain secretion very rarely leads to renal failure, and bone destruction is not seen.

Option C- Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C, the presence of these cryoglobulins in serum leads to Cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by cutaneous vasculitis, palpable purpura, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.

Option D- Senile systemic amyloidosis refers to the systemic deposition of amyloid in elderly patients. The amyloid in this condition is derived from normal TTR (transthyretin). It usually involves the heart.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern of fever for the past five days. He also complains of a headache and malaise. Which of the following is the best screening test to perform now if typhoid is suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best test to screen a symptomatic patient for typhoid in the first week is blood culture.

Enteric fever (typhoid fever) is caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia (fever), abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, and malaise.

Diagnosis of enteric fever:

  • Blood culture: It is more sensitive during 1st week than in the subsequent weeks. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics.

  • Antibody testing: WIDAL test to detect rising titers of H and O agglutinins against salmonella typhi and paratyphi. Agglutinins appear by the end of the first week and rise steadily up to the 3rd or 4th week, after which they disappear.

  • Stool culture: It yields positive results from the 3rd week onwards.

  • Urine culture: Results may be positive after the 2nd week.

  • Bone marrow culture remains positive for 5 days even after the start of antibiotics and is the most sensitive test in the first week. The culture of duodenal aspirate may yield positive results when bone marrow culture is inconclusive.

Empirical treatment of typhoid fever includes management with ceftriaxone 2g/day intravenously for 10-14 days along with azithromycin  1g/day for 5 days. Other antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin, chloramphenicol, and amoxicillin should be considered in resistant cases.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban ?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. They represent a new class of oral anticoagulant drugs that do not require monitoring.

This group of drugs inhibit factor Xa in the final common pathway of clotting [conversion of Prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa)]. They are given as fixed doses and have a rapid onset of action.

Oral direct factor Xa inhibitors are indicated in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

  • Apixaban

  • Argatroban

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. Two days later, he presented to the hospital with a deviation of eyes, inability to open mouth, and torticollis. What is the first-line management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), inability to open the mouth (trismus), asymmetric position of the head and neck (torticollis) are pointing towards a diagnosis of haloperidol-induced acute dystonia. The first-line treatment for antipsychotic-induced acute dystonia is diphenhydramine.

Acute muscular dystonia:

This is an extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that occurs due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors.

Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. 

It occurs most commonly among younger patients and is characterized by muscle spasms involving linguo-facial muscles causing torticollis, locked jaw or trismus, grimacing, tongue thrusting, and oculogyric crisis in severe form.

Treatment:

  1. Anticholinergic agents like benztropine or diphenhydramine, by blocking striatal cholinergic receptors, balance the dopaminergic activity and is given as first-line treatment for dystonia. 
  2. Benzodiazepines (diazepam) antagonizes the excitatory dopaminergic neurons by their GABA agonist action and are used in refractory cases or when anticholinergic use is contraindicated.

Other options:

Option B: Propranolol is used for the management of akathisia.

Option C: Dantrolene is used in the management of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: Lorazepam is used for treating anxiety disorders, alcohol withdrawal, and anesthetic medication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with colicky abdominal pain, joint pain and palpable purpura. Urine analysis shows only red blood cells with no other significant findings. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain and hematuria point towards a diagnosis of IgA vasculitis also known as Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting the hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Abdominal pain
  • Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine.

 The image given below shows palpable purpura in the lower limbs seen in HSP

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are used for the treatment of gastrointestinal manifestations in HSP. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine.

Other options:

Option B: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) is characterized by vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels. It affects the upper respiratory tract (ear, nose, sinuses, and throat), lower respiratory tract (lung), and kidney and is characterized by necrotizing granuloma which is non-caseating.

Option C: Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels. It occurs most commonly in elderly males. Patients can present with non-constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. Renal involvement is very common (79%) in the form of glomerulonephritis, which can rapidly progress, causing renal failure. Lab findings include anemia, raised ESR and or CRP, leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and ANCA positive in 75% of patients, 

Option D: Behcet's disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Here (Th17) T helper 17 cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall.

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
BCG vaccine is primarily used against tuberculosis disease. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. Hence, option D is not true. 

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation (option B) than the liquid vaccine. Currently, the vaccine is distributed in the freeze-dried form because of better storage qualities. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth (option A) and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally (option C) just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

A papule develops at the vaccination site after 2-3 weeks. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Usually, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include prolonged severe ulceration at the vaccination site, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infection. It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the relationship between the occurrence of cancer and pollution levels in their environment. He chose a district with a large number of factories and collected data on cancer in the native population from the district hospitals and the local health centers. What is this type of study known as?
questions.solution:
The study described in the given scenario considers the district population as the unit of study. Therefore, it is an ecological study.

The ecological study is a type of analytical study which analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called correlational study and it uses population as a unit of study.

Other options:

Option B & C: Case-control and cohort studies are also types of analytical studies, but they use individuals as the unit of study. In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls. A cohort study involves a follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease. 

Option D: Experimental studies or interventional studies try to change the determinant or progress of the disease and use the people as the study unit. It includes randomized controlled trials and field and community trials.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fracture of the structure marked below following a road traffic accident. Which of the following symptoms will be seen in this is patient?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid and fracture to the cribriform plate will lead to anosmia as the olfactory nerve fibres pierce through it. 

Olfactory nerves transmit olfactory information from the sensory receptors in the nasal mucosa to the brain. Damage to these fibres can disrupt this pathway, resulting in a loss of smell. A cribriform plate fracture may also lead to a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, manifesting as clear, watery nasal discharge.

The olfactory bulbs are located just above the cribriform plate, as the first relay station for olfactory information. Trauma can cause displacement or direct injury to these bulbs, further disrupting the transmission of olfactory signals. Following trauma, inflammation or swelling can occur in the region, potentially leading to additional damage or pressure on the olfactory nerve fibres and bulbs, exacerbating the loss of smell.

Olfactory nerve fibres pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid and can lead to the spread of infection to the intracranial space and trauma can lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. He also gave a history of two seizure episodes one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. What is the drug of choice in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of high fever. altered sensorium and seizures and peripheral smear showing rings (headphones appearance) points towards the diagnosis of severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria, and the drug of choice for this condition is artesunate.

Artesunate-based combination therapy is given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary. 

If artesunate is unavailable, artemether is given at a dose of 3.2 mg/kg stat IM, followed by 1.6 mg/kg QD, or quinine dihydrochloride is given at a dose of 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2–8 hours.

Major manifestations of severe falciparum malaria include more than two convulsions in 24 hours, unarousable coma/ cerebral malaria (failure to localize or respond appropriately to stimuli or coma persisting for >30 mins after generalized convulsion), acidosis, severe normocytic normochromic anemia, renal failure, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Other manifestations include hemoglobinuria, hyperparasitemia, jaundice, and extreme weakness.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a newborn with weak lower limb pulses and strong upper limb pulses?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of the aorta will be the diagnosis for a newborn with weak lower-limb pulses and strong upper-limb pulses.

Coarctation refers to a constriction or narrowing in the aorta, which can be proximal or distal to the ductus arteriosus. CoA usually presents either in infancy or in later childhood as incidental upper limb hypertension and disparity of pulses in the upper  and lower limbs as radio-femoral delay.

When the ductus arteriosus is open in an infant with severe coarctation, the left-to-right shunt established during birth across the ductus arteriosus during birth is reversed to a right-to-left shunt as there is coarctation above the ductus in the aorta. This leads to deoxygenated blood flow to the lower limbs and no change in pulse in the lower limbs. As the ductus arteriosus closes, there is a pooling of blood in the heart, leading to congestive heart failure, further leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance as well as lack of blood flow to lower limbs (presenting as weak pulses in the lower extremities).

Figure of 3 sign is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta and occurs due to indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinum.

Treatment includes re-establishing patency of the ductus arteriosus by prostaglandin E1 infusion and heart failure medical management followed by definitive surgical management such as coarctectomy, end-to-end anastomosis, or patch aortoplasty. Restenosis of CoA areas later in childhood are common and are treated by balloon angioplasty.

Other options:

Option A: Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by a tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Option C:  Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is a cyanotic congenital anomaly where the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, resulting in systemic and pulmonary circulations existing as two parallel circuits. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. About half of the patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Clinical manifestations become apparent soon after birth, with infants presenting with cyanosis and tachypnea. It is associated with moderate-to-severe hypoxemia.

Option D: Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets. A box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium, which leads to an elevated apex.

questions.text:
A study is conducted to identify the association between vaccination and the development of a disease in a community. Based on the data, 6 vaccinated individuals and 12 unvaccinated individuals developed severe disease. Calculate the relative risk for this community.
  Developed disease Didn't develop disease Total
Vaccinated 6 94 100
Non vaccinated 12 88 100
questions.solution:
The relative risk in this case will be 0.5.

Relative risk is the ratio of the incidence of disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect in a cohort study. 

Here, 

Incidence of disease among exposed (Vaccinated) = 6

Incidence of disease among non-exposed (Unvaccinated) = 12

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence exposed/incidence unexposed = 6/12 = 0.5

Relative Risk

  • The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called the risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a 100% increase in risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is associated with Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:

  • Gilbert syndrome
  • Crigler Najjar type 1
  • Crigler Najjar type 2

Inherited conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

  • Dubin Johnson syndrome (Option B)
  • Rotor syndrome (Option C)

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP - glucuronoyl transferase production. UGT1A1 activity is reduced to 10-33% of normal.

It presents with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with other liver function tests being normal. The disorder is precipitated by stress, alcohol, and reduced caloric intake.

Liver histology shows increased lipofuscin pigment. It responds well to phenobarbitone.

Gilbert's syndrome does not require treatment. The bilirubin levels may fluctuate over time, and patients may occasionally have jaundice, which usually resolves on its own with no ill effects.

UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Option B: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused by mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-coloured pigment.

Option C: Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation and increased conjugated bilirubin levels. The liver biopsy does not show a black-coloured liver.

Option D: Biliary atresia presents with clay-coloured stools, progressive jaundice, persistent alcoholic stools, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). Ultrasonography reveals a triangular cord sign (a hyperechoic area corresponding to the fibrous portion of the bile duct) and a small or absent gallbladder.

questions.text:
A woman arrived at the hospital with edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item purchased from a seller who has now been arrested for food adulteration. Which of the following is the most likely food adulterant used?

Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item purchased from a seller who has now been arrested for food adulteration is suggestive that Sanguinarine is the toxic compound responsible for this.

Sanguinarine causes Epidemic Dropsy.

  • Contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil.
  • Toxic compound: Sanguinarine

Mechanism of action : Sanguinarine interfers with the oxidation of pyruvic acid which in turn accumulates in the blood and causes symptoms.

Clinical presentation: The patient presents with sudden onset, non-inflammatory swelling of bilateral legs which is often associated with diarrhoea. Some patients can develop glaucoma. Dyspnea, cardiac failure and death can occur in later stages.

Tests to detect argemone oil:

  • Nitric acid test
  • Paper chromatography: most sensitive(can detect very low concentration of argemone oil)

Other options:

Option A: Aflatoxins are produced by certain fungi, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, are the most potent hepatotoxins. These fungi can contaminate food grains such as groundnut, maize, parboiled rice, sorghum, wheat, and tapioca. It is mainly due to improper storage. It can be prevented by proper storage after drying. Moisture content should be kept below 10%. They do not cause the symptoms described in the question.

Option C: Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals and Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs is associated with the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus leading to neurolathyrism. 

Option D: Rapidly developing ascites and jaundice is associated with the consumption of millets contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia which contain a toxic pyrrolizidine alkaloid and produce symptoms of endemic ascites, that manifest as rapidly developing ascites and jaundice.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the ER with complaints of muscle twitching and tremors. He gives a history of consuming crushed seeds from a plant. Shortly after, he begins to experience refractory seizures and assumes a characteristic posture with arching of the back and rigid extension of the limbs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests the diagnosis of strychnine poisoning.

Strychnine poisoning occurs if a person ingests crushed seeds of Strychnos nux vomica. If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action. The fatal dose is 15–30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. 

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

Patients typically present with

  • Convulsions are clonic initially but eventually become tonic.
  • Risus sardonicus results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles, in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back.
  • The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension, the posture known as opisthotonus.
  • If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonus).
  • If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

The first step in the management of strychnine poisoning is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates to control seizures, and the patients should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash. Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

Other options :

Option A: Tetanus - Tetanus toxin initially binds to receptors on the presynaptic membranes of motor neurons and migrates to the spinal cord and brainstem. The toxin diﬀuses to inhibitory neurons (γ-aminobutyric acid) from the brainstem and inhibits its function.

Option B: Clostridium - Clostridium tetani secrete 2 types of toxins, namely, tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.  The toxin peptide degrades synaptobrevin, a protein required for the attachment of neurotransmitter vesicles on the presynaptic membrane, before its release. The motor neurons are not inhibited as the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA is blocked. This causes hyperreflexia, muscle spasms, and spastic paralysis result.

Option C: Botulism - Botulinum toxin targets the presynaptic terminals of motor neurons and inhibits the release of acetylcholine. As a result, muscle paralysis occurs, leading to the temporary weakening or cessation of muscle activity in the affected area.

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman is registered in the scheme where a cash incentive of 5000 rupees will be provided to her in installments only for the first living child of the family. What is this scheme?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option C. A cash incentive of 5000 rupees is provided in installments to all pregnant women and lactating mothers under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) for the first living child of the family. This is subject to the fulfillment of specific conditions.

First Installment: Early Registration of pregnancy - 1,000 rupees

Second Installment: Received antenatal care (ANC) at least once (can be claimed after 6 months of pregnancy) - 2,000 rupees

Third Installment: Childbirth is registered and the child has received the first cycle of BCG, OPV, DPT, and hepatitis B vaccine or its equivalent/ substitute - 2,000 rupees

Other options:

Option A: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

PMSMA aims to improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services. This is undertaken as part of the Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child Plus Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) strategy. Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Option B: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits are provided under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative for women and newborns where assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare is provided free of cost.  It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

Option D: Under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who had an institutional delivery in low-performing states. This scheme was launched under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to promote institutional delivery.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presented with failure to thrive and delayed milestones. On examination, he had elevated transaminases and mild hypotonia without any organomegaly. Ophthalmological examination showed a cherry red spot in the macula. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an infant with failure to thrive & delayed milestones, elevated transaminases, and cherry red spot on the macula without organomegaly points to a diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay Sach disease is an autosomal recessive disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. It presents with progressive neurodegeneration, foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages), a “cherry-red” spot on the macula, and developmental delay but does not have hepatosplenomegaly. 

It can present during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and gradual loss of motor skills. Affected children usually die by the age of 10–15 years. 

It is of two types—juvenile-onset and adult-onset. The symptoms of the juvenile-onset form include ataxia and dementia. Dysarthria, lower motor neuron signs, and psychiatric disorders are common in the adult-onset type. 

The image given below shows the cherry-red spot on the macula.

Other options:

Option A:  Niemann Pick disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder due to deficiency of sphingomyelinase leading to accumulation of sphingomyelin. It presents similarly and also has hepatosplenomegaly.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is due to a deficiency of Arylsulfatase A causing central and peripheral demyelination with ataxia, and dementia.

Option C: Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. Presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, osteoporosis, avascular necrosis of the femur, and bone crises. Gaucher cells are lipid-laden macrophages resembling crumpled tissue paper.

questions.text: Which is of the following enzymes is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of NADPH oxidase is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils.

NADPH + 2O2 → NADP+ + 2·O2− + 2H+

NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells (neutrophils, eosinophils, monocytes, and macrophages) produces superoxide anion by reducing oxygen by a process of respiratory burst during phagocytosis.

 There are multiple sources of oxygen radicals in the body:

  • Ionizing radiation (x-rays and UV) causes lysis of water, leading to the formation of hydroxyl radicals.
  • Transition metal ions (Cu+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Fe2+) can react nonenzymatically with oxygen or hydrogen peroxide to form hydroxyl radicals.
  • Nitric oxide can react with superoxide to yield peroxynitrite, which decays to form hydroxyl radicals.
  • NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells produces superoxide radicals.

Other options:

Options A: Catalase is involved in protecting cells from oxidative damage by removing hydrogen peroxide, it is not involved in the generation of reactive oxygen species during the respiratory burst.

Option C: Defensin is an anti-bacterial compound that plays a role in the defense mechanism of the cell.

Option D: Myeloperoxidase is an enzyme found in the granules of neutrophils that uses hydrogen peroxide to produce more potent antimicrobial agents.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analogue that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in de novo purine and thymidylate synthesis. 

It is curative in choriocarcinoma and is used to maintain remission in children with acute leukemias. It has prominent immunosuppressant properties that are useful in rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis and many other autoimmune disorders. When toxicity occurs, it manifests as nausea, loose stool, stomatitis, punctate cutaneous eruption, alopecia and hematologic abnormalities, particularly macrocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common bacteria found as part of the normal flora of the conjunctiva?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is present as a normal flora of conjunctiva.

The normal flora of the conjunctiva consists of a variety of microorganisms that exist harmlessly and help maintain ocular health by preventing the colonization of pathogenic organisms. The most commonly found bacteria in the conjunctiva include:

Staphylococcus epidermidis (most common), staphylococcus aureus, corynebacterium species, streptococcus viridans, propionibacterium acnes, etc.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a novobiocin-sensitive, coagulase-negative, non-pigmented, non-hemolytic cocci. It also doesn't ferment mannitol. 

It is present on normal skin flora and mucous membranes and has the following virulence factors:

  • Biofilms
  • Adhesive proteins
  • Teichoic acids
  • Lipases and DNAses

Among the Coagulase negative staph species, Staph epidermidis is the most common cause of:

  • Healthcare-associated bloodstream infections
  • Early prosthetic valve endocarditis
  • Peritonitis in dialysis patients
  • Infections of orthopedic prosthesis
  • CSF shunt infections

S. epidermidis is more resistant than Staph aureus to methicillin and the treatment of choice is Vancomycin.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic consuming alcohol for the last 20 years had his last drink 3 days back. He presents with altered sensorium, disorientation, tremors, and a feeling of insects crawling over his body. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
    Altered sleep-wake cycle 

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C: Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D: Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients with delirium tremens.

questions.text: Which of the following vectors is associated with Orientia Tsutsugamushi?
questions.solution:
Trombiculid mite is the vector responsible for the transmission of scrub typhus caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. Meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia can be seen in severe cases.

Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK is agglutinated only in scrub typhus. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for both adults and children.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was 45 mg/dL. Yesterday, the patient went to the gym directly after work, following which he attended a party where he only consumed alcoholic beverages and skipped his meals. Which of the following is the likely cause of hypoglycemia in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased  NADH/NAD+ ratio leads to hypoglycemia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who had a history of alcohol intake presenting with hypoglycemia is suggestive of alcohol (ethanol) intoxication that inhibits the process of gluconeogenesis.

Alcohol is metabolized in the liver via the enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase. These reactions convert ethanol to acetaldehyde and then to acetate, using NAD⁺ as a cofactor and producing NADH. The excess NADH shifts the balance of metabolic processes, diverting key substrates (like pyruvate and oxaloacetate) away from gluconeogenesis, thus impairing the liver's ability to produce glucose.

The patient skipped meals at the party, reducing dietary glucose intake, and making them reliant on the liver to maintain blood glucose levels via gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. 

His gym workout would have used up muscle glycogen, further increasing the body’s dependence on hepatic gluconeogenesis for glucose production. Since alcohol inhibits this process, it would exacerbate the hypoglycemia.

 

Other options:

Option A: Thiamine deficiency is not a cause of hypoglycemia but is responsible for causing Wernicke's encephalopathy as well as Korsakoff syndrome in alcoholics. It presents with ophthalmoplegia, confusion, and cerebellar ataxia.

Option C: The HMP shunt is an alternative pathway to glycolysis and is used to produce ribose-5-phosphate and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH). It doesn't cause hypoglycemia

Option D: Alcoholics tend to have an increased NADH/NAD ratio.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman on antidiabetic therapy for the last 10 years has experienced three episodes of vaginal candida infection in the past 2 years. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case of a 50-year-old diabetic patient with recurrent episodes of candidiasis, Canagliflozin must be avoided as it is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, can increase the risk of genital fungal infections, including vaginal candida infections, as it promotes glycosuria (increased glucose in the urine), which can create a favourable environment for yeast growth.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold. 

Other options

Option A : Acarbose: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays the digestion and absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines. It does not directly affect glucose excretion in the urine or fluid removal from the body. Common side effects of acarbose include gastrointestinal disturbances such as flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort.

Option B: Metformin is a biguanide that acts by activation of AMP-dependent protein kinase activation. It mediates a series of actions that help in reducing hepatic gluconeogenesis. It does not affect the blood glucose levels in normoglycemic states and hence does not cause hypoglycemia.

Option D: Pioglitazone is an activator of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ), which is involved in the regulation of genes related to glucose and lipid metabolism. Its adverse effects include increased incidence of heart failure, peripheral edema, weight gain, macular edema, and osteoporosis.

questions.solution:
Gastric lavage will be contraindicated in a case of strychnine poisoning. Strychnine is a highly toxic substance that causes severe convulsions and muscle rigidity, which can lead to complications during the procedure, such as aspiration or further injury due to the patient's agitation or convulsions.

  • Volatile poison
